However, the <fact13>chloride level of 119 mEq/L</fact13> is not significantly decreased, and the <fact16>total protein level of 55 mg/dL</fact16> is mildly elevated, which could be seen in viral meningitis. Given these findings, the best treatment for this patient's most likely diagnosis of viral meningitis would be supportive care, including <fact17>IV fluids and monitoring</fact17>. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 23-year-old man presents to his primary care physician after bleeding from his gums while brushing his teeth for the past week. Although he has had gum bleeding in the past, it has never been this severe. He has no family history available as he was adopted. He does not have any significant past medical history. His physical exam is within normal limits. Screening lab work is ordered with the following values:
Platelet count 330,000/mm3
Bleeding time 6 mins
Prothrombin time 12 sec
Activated partial thromboplastin time 42 sec
Factor VIII activity decreased
Ristocetin cofactor assay decreased
He is subsequently referred to a hematologist for further work-up and treatment. Which of the following aspects of coagulation would most likely be affected?
A) Factor IX
B) Gp Ib
C) Factor XI
D) Vitamin K
E) Antithrombin III
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>23-year-old man</fact1> presents to his primary care physician after <fact2>bleeding from his gums while brushing his teeth for the past week</fact2>. Although he has had gum bleeding in the past, it has never been this severe. He has no family history available as he was adopted. He does not have any significant past medical history. His physical exam is within normal limits. Screening lab work is ordered with the following values: 
<fact3>Platelet count 330,000/mm3</fact3>
<fact4>Bleeding time 6 mins</fact4>
<fact5>Prothrombin time 12 sec</fact5>
<fact6>Activated partial thromboplastin time 42 sec</fact6>
<fact7>Factor VIII activity decreased</fact7>
<fact8>Ristocetin cofactor assay decreased</fact8>
He is subsequently referred to a hematologist for further work-up and treatment. Which of the following aspects of coagulation would most likely be affected?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's lab results, specifically the <fact7>decreased Factor VIII activity</fact7> and <fact8>decreased Ristocetin cofactor assay</fact8>, it suggests a problem with the intrinsic pathway of coagulation and platelet function. The Ristocetin cofactor assay is used to assess the function of von Willebrand factor (vWF), which is a protein that plays a critical role in platelet adhesion and also serves as a carrier for Factor VIII. Therefore, the aspect of coagulation that would most likely be affected is related to vWF, which is closely associated with <fact7>Factor VIII activity</fact7> and platelet function, particularly through the glycoprotein Ib (Gp Ib) receptor on platelets. Thus, the correct answer is {B} Gp Ib.

question:
A 2-month-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her concerned father. He states that ever since her uncomplicated delivery she has failed to gain weight, has had chronic diarrhea, and has had multiple bacterial and viral infections. During the course of the workup, an absent thymic shadow is noted and a lymph node biopsy demonstrates the absence of germinal centers. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
A) Defect in WASP gene
B) Defect in ATM gene
C) Adenosine deaminase deficiency
D) NADPH oxidase deficiency
E) Defect in BTK gene
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>2-month-old girl</fact1> is brought to the pediatrician by her concerned father. He states that ever since her <fact2>uncomplicated delivery</fact2> she has <fact3>failed to gain weight</fact3>, has had <fact4>chronic diarrhea</fact4>, and has had <fact5>multiple bacterial and viral infections</fact5>. During the course of the workup, an <fact6>absent thymic shadow</fact6> is noted and a <fact7>lymph node biopsy</fact7> demonstrates the <fact8>absence of germinal centers</fact8>. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>2-month-old girl's</fact1> symptoms, including <fact3>failure to gain weight</fact3>, <fact4>chronic diarrhea</fact4>, and <fact5>multiple bacterial and viral infections</fact5> since her <fact2>uncomplicated delivery</fact2>, along with the findings of an <fact6>absent thymic shadow</fact6> and the <fact8>absence of germinal centers</fact8> on <fact7>lymph node biopsy</fact7>, it is suggestive of a severe immunodeficiency. The combination of these clinical and histopathological features points towards a condition affecting both cellular and humoral immunity. Among the options provided, a deficiency in adenosine deaminase (ADA) is known to cause severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), characterized by impaired development of T cells and sometimes B cells, leading to severe infections and failure to thrive, which aligns with the patient's presentation. Therefore, the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is {C}.

question:
A 14-year-old girl presents with sudden drooping of the right side of her face with drooling and excessive tearing. The patient’s mother says that the patient was recently in northern Maine and spent most of her time during the trip outdoors. Physical examination reveals a slight asymmetry of the facial muscles with an inability to whistle or close the right eye. A circular red rash with central clearing is present on the trunk. There is also decreased taste sensation. Which of the following most likely transmitted the organism responsible for this patient’s illness?
A) Ixodes scapularis
B) Tsetse fly
C) Culicidae
D) Dermacentor variabilis
E) Anopheles
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>14-year-old girl</fact1> presents with <fact2>sudden drooping of the right side of her face</fact2> with <fact3>drooling and excessive tearing</fact3>. The patient’s mother says that the patient was recently in <fact4>nthern Maine</fact4> and spent most of her time during the trip <fact5>outdoors</fact5>. Physical examination reveals a <fact6>slight asymmetry of the facial muscles</fact6> with an <fact7>inability to whistle or close the right eye</fact7>. A <fact8>circular red rash with central clearing</fact8> is present on the trunk. There is also <fact9>decreased taste sensation</fact9>. Which of the following most likely transmitted the organism responsible for this patient’s illness?

Answer: 
Analyzing the situation, the <fact1>14-year-old girl</fact1> presents with symptoms consistent with Bell's palsy or Lyme disease, such as <fact2>sudden drooping of the right side of her face</fact2> and <fact3>drooling and excessive tearing</fact3>. The presence of a <fact8>circular red rash with central clearing</fact8> is highly indicative of erythema migrans, a characteristic rash of Lyme disease. Lyme disease is commonly transmitted by ticks, specifically the black-legged tick (Ixodes scapularis), which is prevalent in <fact4>northern Maine</fact4> and other wooded areas where the patient spent time <fact5>outdoors</fact5>. Therefore, the most likely transmitter of the organism responsible for this patient's illness is {A}.

question:
A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for the evaluation of fatigue for several weeks. The parents report that their son quit doing sports at school because of low energy. The patient's academic performance has declined recently. He spends most of his time in the basement playing video games and eating bowls of cereal. He has no history of serious illness. His mother has Hashimoto's thyroiditis and his father has major depressive disorder. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows conjunctival pallor, inflammation and fissuring of the corners of the mouth, and concavity of the finger nails. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 11.5 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 76 μm3
Platelet count 290,000/mm3
Red cell distribution width 18% (N = 13%–15%)
Leukocyte count 7,000/mm3
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in treatment?"
A) Regular blood transfusions
B) Fluoxetine
C) Methylphenidate
D) Iron supplementation
E) Allogenic stem cell transplantation
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>16-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to the physician by his parents for the evaluation of <fact2>fatigue for several weeks</fact2>. The parents report that their son quit doing sports at school because of <fact3>low energy</fact3>. The patient's academic performance has declined recently. He spends most of his time in the basement playing video games and eating bowls of cereal. He has no history of serious illness. His mother has <fact4>Hashimoto's thyroiditis</fact4> and his father has <fact5>major depressive disorder</fact5>. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows <fact6>conjunctival pallor</fact6>, <fact7>inflammation and fissuring of the corners of the mouth</fact7>, and <fact8>concavity of the finger nails</fact8>. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
<fact9>Hemoglobin 11.5 g/dL</fact9>
<fact10>Mean corpuscular volume 76 μm3</fact10>
<fact11>Platelet count 290,000/mm3</fact11>
<fact12>Red cell distribution width 18% (N = 13%–15%)</fact12>
<fact13>Leukocyte count 7,000/mm3</fact13>
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in treatment?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>fatigue for several weeks</fact2> and <fact3>low energy</fact3>, along with the physical examination findings of <fact6>conjunctival pallor</fact6>, <fact7>inflammation and fissuring of the corners of the mouth</fact7>, and <fact8>concavity of the finger nails</fact8>, these are indicative of iron deficiency anemia. The laboratory results support this diagnosis with a <fact9>low hemoglobin level of 11.5 g/dL</fact9>, <fact10>low mean corpuscular volume of 76 μm3</fact10> indicating microcytic anemia, and an <fact12>elevated red cell distribution width of 18%</fact12> suggesting a variation in red blood cell size. Given these findings, the most appropriate initial step in treatment is iron supplementation to address the iron deficiency anemia. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 78-year-old right-handed man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter for sudden onset speech changes. The patient lives with his daughter and was chatting with her when suddenly his speech became distorted with random and disconnected words that made no sense. He seems to be physically frustrated that no one understands him. Physical examination demonstrates weakness of the right arm. Damage to which location would best explain this patient’s symptoms?
A) Left frontal lobe
B) Left internal capsule
C) Left temporal lobe
D) Right frontal lobe
E) Right temporal lobe
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>78-year-old right-handed man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department by his daughter for <fact2>sudden onset speech changes</fact2>. The patient lives with his daughter and was chatting with her when suddenly his <fact3>speech became distorted with random and disconnected words that made no sense</fact3>. He seems to be physically frustrated that no one understands him. Physical examination demonstrates <fact4>weakness of the right arm</fact4>. Damage to which location would best explain this patient’s symptoms?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms, the <fact1>78-year-old right-handed man</fact1> experienced <fact2>sudden onset speech changes</fact2> characterized by <fact3>speech becoming distorted with random and disconnected words that made no sense</fact3>, indicating a possible aphasia. Additionally, the physical examination revealed <fact4>weakness of the right arm</fact4>. Given that the patient is right-handed, this suggests a left-sided brain lesion affecting both language processing and motor control. The left frontal lobe, particularly Broca's area, is responsible for speech production, and damage to this area can result in Broca's aphasia, which is consistent with the patient's symptoms. Therefore, damage to the left frontal lobe would best explain this patient's symptoms. The answer is {A}.

question:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of intermittent chest pain and palpitations. She also complains of dyspnea on exertion and has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss in the past 2 months despite normal appetite. She has no history of serious medical illness. Cardiac examination shows an irregularly irregular rhythm and a grade 3/6, low pitched, rumbling, mid-diastolic murmur heard best over the apex. Diffuse wheezing and bilateral rales are present in the lung bases. A transthoracic echocardiogram shows a left-ventricular ejection fraction of 40% and a mass in the left atrium. A biopsy of the mass is likely to show which of the following?
A) Nonencapsulated groups of well-differentiated skeletal muscle cells
B) Clusters of bland cells without mitotic activity
C) Mixture of cells from different germinal layers
D) Encapsulated cluster of mature fat cells
E) Nests of atypical melanocytes
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>45-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the emergency department because of <fact2>intermittent chest pain and palpitations</fact2>. She also complains of <fact3>dyspnea on exertion</fact3> and has had a <fact4>4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss in the past 2 months</fact4> despite normal appetite. She has no history of serious medical illness. Cardiac examination shows an <fact5>irregularly irregular rhythm</fact5> and a <fact6>grade 3/6, low pitched, rumbling, mid-diastolic murmur heard best over the apex</fact6>. <fact7>Diffuse wheezing and bilateral rales</fact7> are present in the lung bases. A <fact8>transthoracic echocardiogram</fact8> shows a <fact9>left-ventricular ejection fraction of 40%</fact9> and a <fact10>mass in the left atrium</fact10>. A biopsy of the mass is likely to show which of the following?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>intermittent chest pain and palpitations</fact2>, <fact3>dyspnea on exertion</fact3>, and significant <fact4>weight loss</fact4>, along with the findings of an <fact5>irregularly irregular rhythm</fact5> and a <fact6>mid-diastolic murmur</fact6>, the presence of a <fact10>mass in the left atrium</fact10> as seen on the <fact8>transthoracic echocardiogram</fact8> is highly suggestive of a cardiac myxoma. This condition is often associated with systemic symptoms and can cause obstructive symptoms due to its location within the heart. The characteristic histological appearance of a cardiac myxoma includes <fact11>clusters of bland cells without mitotic activity</fact11>, which are typically found in a myxoid background. Therefore, the most likely finding on biopsy of the mass is option {B}.

question:
A 27-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 38 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital for active labor. The pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes and fetal weight is estimated to be at the 90th percentile for gestational age. During delivery, there is an arrest in the second stage of labor, and a vacuum-assisted delivery is performed. Postpartum examination shows a third-degree laceration in the vagina extending into the perineum at the 6 o'clock position. This patient is most likely to experience which of the following complications?
A) Urge incontinence
B) Vesicovaginal fistula
C) Fecal incontinence
D) Small bowel obstruction
E) Stress incontinence
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>27-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 38 weeks' gestation</fact1> is admitted to the hospital for <fact2>active labor</fact2>. The pregnancy was complicated by <fact3>gestational diabetes</fact3> and fetal weight is estimated to be at the <fact4>90th percentile for gestational age</fact4>. During delivery, there is an <fact5>arrest in the second stage of labor</fact5>, and a <fact6:vacuum-assisted delivery</fact6> is performed. Postpartum examination shows a <fact7>third-degree laceration in the vagina extending into the perineum at the 6 o'clock position</fact7>. This patient is most likely to experience which of the following complications?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact7>third-degree laceration in the vagina extending into the perineum at the 6 o'clock position</fact7>, this type of injury can damage the anal sphincter and potentially lead to issues with bowel control. Therefore, the patient is most likely to experience {C} Fecal incontinence.

question:
A 36-year-old woman presents with increased tiredness and lethargy for the past 4 weeks. Investigations show her hemoglobin level to be 8.6 gm/dL and serum creatinine of 4.6 mg/dL. The serum is negative for antinuclear antibodies (ANA) and positive for C3 nephritic factor. Urinalysis shows a 3+ proteinuria. The renal biopsy demonstrates hypercellular glomerulus with electron dense deposits along the glomerular basement membrane. What is the most likely cause?
A) Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN)
B) Membrano proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN)
C) Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN)
D) Minimal change disease
E) Membranous glomerulonephritis (MGN)
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>36-year-old woman</fact1> presents with <fact2>increased tiredness and lethargy</fact2> for the past 4 weeks. Investigations show her <fact3>hemoglobin level to be 8.6 gm/dL</fact3> and <fact4>serum creatinine of 4.6 mg/dL</fact4>. The serum is <fact5>negative for antinuclear antibodies (ANA)</fact5> and <fact6>positive for C3 nephritic factor</fact6>. Urinalysis shows a <fact7>3+ proteinuria</fact7>. The <fact8>renal biopsy demonstrates hypercellular glomerulus with electron dense deposits along the glomerular basement membrane</fact8>. What is the most likely cause?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation, the <fact1>36-year-old woman</fact1> has <fact2>increased tiredness and lethargy</fact2> likely due to her low <fact3>hemoglobin level of 8.6 gm/dL</fact3> and impaired renal function indicated by a <fact4>serum creatinine of 4.6 mg/dL</fact4>. The absence of <fact5>antinuclear antibodies (ANA)</fact5> makes autoimmune causes less likely. However, the presence of <fact6>C3 nephritic factor</fact6> is a strong indicator of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN), a condition characterized by the activation of the alternative complement pathway. Additionally, the <fact7>3+ proteinuria</fact7> and the findings from the <fact8>renal biopsy showing hypercellular glomerulus with electron dense deposits along the glomerular basement membrane</fact8> are consistent with MPGN. Therefore, the most likely cause is {B}.

question:
A 67-year-old man with peripheral neuropathy comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after the results of serum protein electrophoresis showed monoclonal gammopathy. A complete blood count, serum creatinine, and serum electrolyte concentrations are within the reference ranges. A bone marrow biopsy shows 6% monoclonal plasma cells. Further analysis shows that class I major histocompatibility molecules are downregulated in these monoclonal plasma cells. The proliferation of these monoclonal plasma cells is normally prevented by a class of immune cells that lyse abnormal cells without the need for opsonization, priming, or prior activation. Which of the following best describes this class of immune cells?
A) CD8+ T lymphocytes
B) Bone marrow-derived macrophages
C) CD4+ T lymphocytes
D) Natural killer cells
E) Band neutrophils
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>67-year-old man</fact1> with <fact2>peripheral neuropathy</fact2> comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after the results of <fact3>serum protein electrophoresis showed monoclonal gammopathy</fact3>. A <fact4>complete blood count, serum creatinine, and serum electrolyte concentrations are within the reference ranges</fact4>. A <fact5>bone marrow biopsy shows 6% monoclonal plasma cells</fact5>. Further analysis shows that <fact6>class I major histocompatibility molecules are downregulated in these monoclonal plasma cells</fact6>. The proliferation of these monoclonal plasma cells is normally prevented by a class of immune cells that <fact7>lyse abnormal cells without the need for opsonization, priming, or prior activation</fact7>. Which of the following best describes this class of immune cells?

Answer: 
Considering the information provided, the key to answering this question lies in understanding the type of immune cells that can <fact7>lyse abnormal cells without the need for opsonization, priming, or prior activation</fact7> and can target cells with <fact6>downregulated class I major histocompatibility molecules</fact6>. Among the options provided, natural killer cells are known for their ability to recognize and destroy cells that have downregulated MHC class I expression, which is a common mechanism used by some pathogens and cancer cells to evade immune detection. This function is critical in preventing the proliferation of abnormal cells, such as the <fact5>monoclonal plasma cells</fact5> identified in the patient's <fact5>bone marrow biopsy</fact5>. Therefore, the correct answer is {D}.

question:
A 72-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of frequent headaches, double vision, fatigue, and myalgias. Physical examination shows pallor, tenderness to palpation over the temples, and inward deviation of the left eye. Laboratory studies show an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 65 mm/h. Temporal artery biopsy shows transmural granulomatous inflammation and fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina. Treatment with high-dose intravenous corticosteroids is begun. The patient's condition puts her at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?
A) Pulmonary hypertension
B) Lower extremity gangrene
C) Palpable purpura
D) Posterior uveitis
E) Thoracic aortic aneurysm
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>72-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of a <fact2>1-month history of frequent headaches, double vision, fatigue, and myalgias</fact2>. Physical examination shows <fact3>pallor, tenderness to palpation over the temples, and inward deviation of the left eye</fact3>. Laboratory studies show an <fact4>erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 65 mm/h</fact4>. <fact5>Temporal artery biopsy</fact5> shows <fact6>transmural granulomatous inflammation and fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina</fact6>. Treatment with <fact7>high-dose intravenous corticosteroids</fact7> is begun. The patient's condition puts her at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms, including <fact2>frequent headaches, double vision, fatigue, and myalgias</fact2>, along with the physical examination findings of <fact3>pallor, tenderness to palpation over the temples, and inward deviation of the left eye</fact3>, the diagnosis is consistent with Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA). This is further supported by the elevated <fact4>erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 65 mm/h</fact4> and the <fact5>temporal artery biopsy</fact5> showing <fact6>transmural granulomatous inflammation and fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina</fact6>. Given the diagnosis of GCA, one of the most significant complications is visual loss, which can occur due to ischemia of the optic nerve or retina. However, among the provided options, the most relevant complication related to GCA is not directly listed, but considering the vascular nature of GCA, there is an increased risk of aortic aneurysms, including a <fact8>thoracic aortic aneurysm</fact8>. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 4-year-old previously healthy boy presents with 4 days of intermittent vomiting and 5-6 daily loose stools. His mother noted bloody stools and decreased oral intake of food and water over the last 24 hours. He is normally in daycare; however, he has been home for the past 3 days. On physical exam his temperature is 102.2°F (39°C), blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 22/min and O2 saturation is 99% on room air. He has dry mucous membranes. On abdominal exam you note diffuse tenderness to palpation without rebound or guarding. There are no masses, hepatosplenomegaly, and bowel sounds are hyperactive. Ultrasound of the right lower quadrant is negative for appendicitis. Stool is guaiac positive. He receives 15mg/kg acetaminophen and fluids are started. The next day, he complains of lower extremity weakness and tingling. On repeat exam, lower extremity strength is 3/5 with diminished patellar deep tendon reflexes. Which of the following lab findings would most likely be seen in this patient?
A) Gram stain positive CSF
B) Peripheral eosinophilia
C) Xanthochromia on cerebrospinal fluid analysis
D) Increased cerebrospinal fluid protein with normal cell count
E) Oligoclonal bands on cerebrospinal fluid analysis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>4-year-old previously healthy boy</fact1> presents with <fact2>4 days of intermittent vomiting and 5-6 daily loose stools</fact2>. His mother noted <fact3>bloody stools and decreased oral intake of food and water over the last 24 hours</fact3>. He is normally in daycare; however, he has been home for the past 3 days. On physical exam his <fact4>temperature is 102.2°F (39°C)</fact4>, <fact5>blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg</fact5>, <fact6>pulse is 120/min</fact6>, <fact7>respirations are 22/min</fact7> and <fact8>O2 saturation is 99% on room air</fact8>. He has <fact9>dry mucous membranes</fact9>. On abdominal exam you note <fact10>diffuse tenderness to palpation without rebound or guarding</fact10>. There are no masses, hepatosplenomegaly, and <fact11>bowel sounds are hyperactive</fact11>. Ultrasound of the right lower quadrant is negative for appendicitis. Stool is <fact12>guaiac positive</fact12>. He receives <fact13>15mg/kg acetaminophen</fact13> and fluids are started. The next day, he complains of <fact14>lower extremity weakness and tingling</fact14>. On repeat exam, <fact15>lower extremity strength is 3/5 with diminished patellar deep tendon reflexes</fact15>. Which of the following lab findings would most likely be seen in this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>intermittent vomiting and daily loose stools</fact2>, followed by <fact3>bloody stools</fact3>, and the development of <fact14>lower extremity weakness and tingling</fact14> with <fact15>diminished patellar deep tendon reflexes</fact15>, the clinical presentation is suggestive of Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS), a rare autoimmune disorder that can be triggered by gastrointestinal infections. GBS is characterized by muscle weakness and diminished or absent deep tendon reflexes. Among the provided options, the most likely lab finding in GBS would be an <fact16>increased cerebrospinal fluid protein with normal cell count</fact16>, which is a common feature of this condition. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A stillborn infant is delivered at 38 weeks' gestation to a 32-year-old woman. The mother had no prenatal care. Examination of the stillborn shows a small pelvis, shallow intergluteal cleft, and club feet. An x-ray shows the absence of the sacrum and lumbar vertebrae. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
A) Maternal oligohydramnios
B) Intrauterine alcohol exposure
C) Chromosome 13 trisomy
D) Maternal diabetes
E) Chromosome 18 trisomy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A stillborn infant is delivered at <fact1>38 weeks' gestation</fact1> to a <fact2>32-year-old woman</fact2>. The mother had <fact3>no prenatal care</fact3>. Examination of the stillborn shows a <fact4>small pelvis</fact4>, <fact5>shallow intergluteal cleft</fact5>, and <fact6>club feet</fact6>. An x-ray shows the <fact7>absence of the sacrum and lumbar vertebrae</fact7>. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?

Answer: 
Analyzing the situation, the stillborn infant delivered at <fact1>38 weeks' gestation</fact1> has a <fact4>small pelvis</fact4>, <fact5>shallow intergluteal cleft</fact5>, and <fact6>club feet</fact6>, with an x-ray showing the <fact7>absence of the sacrum and lumbar vertebrae</fact7>. These findings are characteristic of caudal regression syndrome, a condition strongly associated with maternal diabetes. Therefore, the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition is {D}.

question:
A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine bone mineral density screening. She does not have any children. Menopause was at age 55. Her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 48 years. She has hypertension for which she takes ramipril. Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry at the femoral neck shows a T-score of -2.7 SD. The physician considers treatment with raloxifene. This medication would put her at increased risk of developing which of the following conditions?
A) Pulmonary embolism
B) Cellulitis
C) Breast cancer
D) Mandibular osteonecrosis
E) Hypercholesterolemia
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>65-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician for a routine <fact2>bone mineral density screening</fact2>. She does not have any children. <fact3>Menopause was at age 55</fact3>. Her mother died of <fact4>breast cancer</fact4> at the age of 48 years. She has <fact5>hypertension</fact5> for which she takes <fact6>ramipril</fact6>. <fact7>Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry at the femoral neck</fact7> shows a <fact8>T-score of -2.7 SD</fact8>. The physician considers treatment with <fact9>raloxifene</fact9>. This medication would put her at increased risk of developing which of the following conditions?

Answer: 
Considering the treatment with <fact9>raloxifene</fact9> for the <fact1>65-year-old woman</fact1> with a <fact8>T-score of -2.7 SD</fact8> indicating osteoporosis, it is essential to be aware of the potential risks associated with this medication. Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that has been linked to an increased risk of thromboembolic events. Given this information, the condition that raloxifene would put her at increased risk of developing is a <fact10>pulmonary embolism</fact10>, which is a type of thromboembolic event. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
Two weeks after undergoing an emergency cardiac catherization with stenting for unstable angina pectoris, a 61-year-old man has decreased urinary output and malaise. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and osteoarthritis of the hips. Prior to admission, his medications were insulin and naproxen. He was also started on aspirin, clopidogrel, and metoprolol after the coronary intervention. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 93/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. Examination shows mottled, reticulated purplish discoloration of the feet. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin count 14 g/dL
Leukocyte count 16,400/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 56%
Eosinophils 11%
Lymphocytes 31%
Monocytes 2%
Platelet count 260,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 68 mm/h
Serum
Urea nitrogen 25 mg/dL
Creatinine 4.2 mg/dL
Renal biopsy shows intravascular spindle-shaped vacuoles. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?"
A) Renal papillary necrosis
B) Allergic interstitial nephritis
C) Cholesterol embolization
D) Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis
E) Polyarteritis nodosa
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>61-year-old man</fact1> has decreased urinary output and malaise two weeks after undergoing an emergency <fact2>cardiac catherization with stenting for unstable angina pectoris</fact2>. He has <fact3>type 2 diabetes mellitus</fact3> and <fact4>osteoarthritis of the hips</fact4>. Prior to admission, his medications were <fact5>insulin</fact5> and <fact6>naproxen</fact6>. He was also started on <fact7>aspirin</fact7>, <fact8>clopidogrel</fact8>, and <fact9>metoprolol</fact9> after the coronary intervention. His <fact10>temperature is 38°C (100.4°F)</fact10>, <fact11>pulse is 93/min</fact11>, and <fact12>blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg</fact12>. Examination shows <fact13>mottled, reticulated purplish discoloration of the feet</fact13>. Laboratory studies show: 
<fact14>Hemoglobin count 14 g/dL</fact14> 
<fact15>Leukocyte count 16,400/mm3</fact15> 
<fact16>Segmented neutrophils 56%</fact16> 
<fact17>Eosinophils 11%</fact17> 
<fact18>Lymphocytes 31%</fact18> 
<fact19>Monocytes 2%</fact19> 
<fact20>Platelet count 260,000/mm3</fact20> 
<fact21>Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 68 mm/h</fact21> 
<fact22>Serum Urea nitrogen 25 mg/dL</fact22> 
<fact23>Creatinine 4.2 mg/dL</fact23> 
<fact24>Renal biopsy shows intravascular spindle-shaped vacuoles</fact24>. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's recent history of <fact2>cardiac catherization with stenting for unstable angina pectoris</fact2> and the presence of <fact13>mottled, reticulated purplish discoloration of the feet</fact13>, along with the laboratory findings of <fact23>elevated creatinine</fact23> and <fact24>renal biopsy showing intravascular spindle-shaped vacuoles</fact24>, the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is cholesterol embolization. Cholesterol embolization syndrome can occur after invasive vascular procedures and is characterized by the release of cholesterol crystals into the bloodstream, leading to embolization in smaller vessels, including those in the kidneys and skin. The patient's presentation and biopsy findings are consistent with this diagnosis. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 7 -day-old newborn boy presents to the emergency department with a history of fever, irritability, and generalized erythema. During the first 2 days of clinical manifestations, the parents of the child tried to control the symptoms using acetaminophen; however, the newborn continued to be ill, and blisters were noticeable around the buttocks, hands, and feet. During the physical examination, the vital signs include body temperature 39.0°C (102.3°F), heart rate 130/min, and respiratory rate 45/min. Ears, nose, and oral mucosa preserved their integrity, while the skin presents with diffuse blanching erythema and flaccid blisters with a positive Nikolsky’s sign. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A) Scarlet fever
B) Scalded skin syndrome
C) Impetigo
D) Erysipela
E) Pyoderma
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>7-day-old newborn boy</fact1> presents to the emergency department with a history of <fact2>fever, irritability, and generalized erythema</fact2>. During the first <fact3>2 days of clinical manifestations</fact3>, the parents of the child tried to control the symptoms using <fact4>acetaminophen</fact4>; however, the newborn continued to be ill, and <fact5>blisters were noticeable around the buttocks, hands, and feet</fact5>. During the physical examination, the vital signs include <fact6>body temperature 39.0°C (102.3°F)</fact6>, <fact7>heart rate 130/min</fact7>, and <fact8>respiratory rate 45/min</fact8>. <fact9>Ears, nose, and oral mucosa preserved their integrity</fact9>, while the skin presents with <fact10>diffuse blanching erythema and flaccid blisters with a positive Nikolsky’s sign</fact10>. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's age as a <fact1>7-day-old newborn boy</fact1> and the symptoms of <fact2>fever, irritability, and generalized erythema</fact2> that progressed to <fact5>blisters around the buttocks, hands, and feet</fact5> despite the use of <fact4>acetaminophen</fact4> for <fact3>2 days</fact3>, along with the physical examination findings of <fact10>diffuse blanching erythema and flaccid blisters with a positive Nikolsky’s sign</fact10>, the most likely diagnosis is Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS). The presence of a <fact10>positive Nikolsky’s sign</fact10> is particularly indicative of SSSS, as it suggests that the blisters are easily ruptured, leaving denuded skin. The fact that the <fact9>ears, nose, and oral mucosa preserved their integrity</fact9> also supports this diagnosis, as SSSS typically spares mucous membranes. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 25-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider for evaluation of a "painful mass in my left groin." She says that her symptoms began 4 days ago as a painful mass that slowly enlarged, ruptured, and ulcerated. However, she denies fever, chills, dysuria, or hematuria. Three weeks prior to her current symptoms she noted a small, painless ulcer on her labium majorum that resolved after a few days. She admits to having unprotected sex with a male partner a month ago while she was traveling in Southeast Asia. Temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 139/84 mmHg, pulse is 76/min, and respirations are 18/min. Physical examination is significant for left-sided, tender, ulcerative lymph nodes with a dark discoloration. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in this patient's condition?
A) Donovan bodies on Wright-Giemsa stain
B) Gram-negative rods in school of fish formation on Gram stain
C) PCR positive for Chlamydia trachomatis
D) Positive RPR, VDRL, and FTA-ABS
E) Tzanck smear with multinucleated giant cells
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>25-year-old woman</fact1> presents to her primary care provider for evaluation of a "<fact2>painful mass in my left groin</fact2>." She says that her symptoms began <fact3>4 days ago</fact3> as a <fact4>painful mass that slowly enlarged, ruptured, and ulcerated</fact4>. However, she denies <fact5>fever, chills, dysuria, or hematuria</fact5>. <fact6>Three weeks prior to her current symptoms</fact6> she noted a <fact7>small, painless ulcer on her labium majorum</fact7> that resolved after a few days. She admits to having <fact8>unprotected sex with a male partner a month ago</fact8> while she was traveling in <fact9>Southeast Asia</fact9>. <fact10>Temperature is 99°F (37.2°C)</fact10>, <fact11>blood pressure is 139/84 mmHg</fact11>, <fact12>pulse is 76/min</fact12>, and <fact13>respirations are 18/min</fact13>. Physical examination is significant for <fact14>left-sided, tender, ulcerative lymph nodes with a dark discoloration</fact14>. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in this patient's condition?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms, particularly the <fact2>painful mass in the left groin</fact2> that <fact4>enlarged, ruptured, and ulcerated</fact4>, along with the presence of a <fact7>small, painless ulcer on her labium majorum</fact7> <fact6>three weeks prior to her current symptoms</fact6>, suggests an infection likely acquired through <fact8>unprotected sex</fact8>. The physical examination finding of <fact14>left-sided, tender, ulcerative lymph nodes with a dark discoloration</fact14> further supports a diagnosis related to a sexually transmitted infection. Among the options provided, the most likely condition related to these symptoms and findings is lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 22-year-old woman with a history of asthma visits her physician for worsening shortness of breath. She states that she feels as though her “lungs are falling apart,” noting that her lung function has been steadily deteriorating. She further states that she has visited a number of other physicians who prescribed several different types of inhalers, but she feels that they have not helped her control her asthma exacerbations. She has experienced 4 episodes of pneumonia in the last 3 years and often suffers from “random” bouts of excessive coughing and wheezing. When asked if her coughing episodes produce sputum, she states, “Yes, the stuff is greenish with specks of red in it.” She also states that her coughing and wheezing episodes are associated with fever, malaise, and occasional expectoration of brown mucous plugs. The vital signs include: blood pressure 122/70 mm Hg, pulse 66/min, respiratory rate 26/min, and temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical exam, the patient appears frail-looking and in moderate respiratory distress. Auscultation reveals inspiratory crackles in the right lung base and coarse breath sounds in the bilateral upper lung lobes. Chest radiograph, as shown below, reveals atelectasis in the right lung base. There are also branched radiodensities that the radiologist notes as being “glove-finger shadows” (noted by the arrow in the image). Serum immunoglobulin E (IgE) levels are elevated. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy in this patient?
A) Isoniazid
B) Fluconazole
C) Caspofungin
D) Prednisone
E) Surgical resection of the infiltrates
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>22-year-old woman</fact1> with a history of <fact2>asthma</fact2> visits her physician for worsening <fact3>shortness of breath</fact3>. She states that she feels as though her “lungs are falling apart,” noting that her <fact4>lung function has been steadily deteriorating</fact4>. She further states that she has visited a number of other physicians who prescribed several different types of <fact5>inhalers</fact5>, but she feels that they have not helped her control her <fact6>asthma exacerbations</fact6>. She has experienced <fact7>4 episodes of pneumonia in the last 3 years</fact7> and often suffers from “random” bouts of excessive <fact8>coughing and wheezing</fact8>. When asked if her <fact9>coughing episodes produce sputum</fact9>, she states, “Yes, the stuff is <fact10>greenish with specks of red in it</fact10>.” She also states that her <fact11>coughing and wheezing episodes are associated with fever, malaise, and occasional expectoration of brown mucous plugs</fact11>. The <fact12>vital signs</fact12> include: <fact13>blood pressure 122/70 mm Hg</fact13>, <fact14>pulse 66/min</fact14>, <fact15>respiratory rate 26/min</fact15>, and <fact16>temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F)</fact16>. On <fact17>physical exam</fact17>, the patient appears <fact18>frail-looking and in moderate respiratory distress</fact18>. <fact19>Auscultation reveals inspiratory crackles in the right lung base and coarse breath sounds in the bilateral upper lung lobes</fact19>. <fact20>Chest radiograph</fact20> reveals <fact21>atelectasis in the right lung base</fact21>. There are also <fact22>branched radiodensities that the radiologist notes as being “glove-finger shadows”</fact22> (noted by the arrow in the image). <fact23>Serum immunoglobulin E (IgE) levels are elevated</fact23>. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy in this patient?

Answer:
Considering the patient's history of <fact2>asthma</fact2> and the presence of <fact22>branched radiodensities that the radiologist notes as being “glove-finger shadows”</fact22> on the <fact20>chest radiograph</fact20>, which are indicative of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), the most appropriate therapy would be to manage the allergic response and reduce inflammation. Elevated <fact23>serum immunoglobulin E (IgE) levels</fact23> further support the diagnosis of ABPA. Given these factors, the most appropriate therapy is the use of systemic corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and manage symptoms. Therefore, the answer is {D} Prednisone.

question:
A 30-year-old male presents to his primary care physician complaining of infertility. He and his wife have been trying to get pregnant for the past two years. They have used fertility monitors and other aids without success. A hysterosalpingogram in his wife was normal. The patient has a history of cleft lip and recurrent upper respiratory infections as a child. He was briefly hospitalized for severe pneumonia when he was 9-years-old. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 120/85 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 18/min. On examination, he is a healthy-appearing male in no acute distress with fully developed reproductive organs. Notably, cardiac auscultation is silent in the left 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. This patient most likely has a mutation in which of the following classes of proteins?
A) Microtubule monomeric protein
B) Lysosomal trafficking regulator protein
C) Transmembrane ion channel protein
D) Retrograde cytoskeletal motor protein
E) Anterograde cytoskeletal motor protein
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>30-year-old male</fact1> presents to his primary care physician complaining of <fact2>infertility</fact2>. He and his wife have been trying to get pregnant for the past two years. They have used fertility monitors and other aids without success. A <fact3>hysterosalpingogram in his wife was normal</fact3>. The patient has a history of <fact4>cleft lip</fact4> and <fact5>recurrent upper respiratory infections as a child</fact5>. He was briefly hospitalized for <fact6>severe pneumonia when he was 9-years-old</fact6>. His <fact7>temperature is 98.6°F (37°C)</fact7>, <fact8>blood pressure is 120/85 mmHg</fact8>, <fact9>pulse is 90/min</fact9>, and <fact10>respirations are 18/min</fact10>. On examination, he is a healthy-appearing male in no acute distress with fully developed reproductive organs. Notably, <fact11>cardiac auscultation is silent in the left 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line</fact11>. This patient most likely has a mutation in which of the following classes of proteins?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's history of <fact4>cleft lip</fact4>, <fact5>recurrent upper respiratory infections as a child</fact5>, and <fact6>severe pneumonia when he was 9-years-old</fact6>, along with the notable finding of <fact11>silent cardiac auscultation in the left 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line</fact11>, it suggests a condition that affects ciliary function. This pattern of symptoms is consistent with Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (PCD), also known as Kartagener syndrome when situs inversus is present. PCD is caused by mutations in genes encoding proteins involved in the structure and function of cilia, specifically affecting the dynein arms that are crucial for ciliary motility. Dynein is a type of <fact12>retrograde cytoskeletal motor protein</fact12> essential for the movement of cilia and flagella. Therefore, the patient most likely has a mutation in a retrograde cytoskeletal motor protein. The answer is {D}.

question:
A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of a painless right-sided scrotal swelling. The swelling started several weeks ago but is not always present. Physical examination shows an 8-cm, soft, cystic nontender right-sided scrotal mass that transilluminates. The mass does not increase in size on coughing and it is possible to palpate normal tissue above the mass. There are no bowel sounds in the mass, and it does not reduce when the patient is in a supine position. Examination of the testis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the mass?
A) Imbalance of fluid secretion and resorption by tunica vaginalis
B) Failure of processus vaginalis to obliterate
C) Extension of abdominal contents through the inguinal canal
D) Dilation and tortuosity of veins in the pampiniform plexus
E) Primary germ cell neoplasia of the testicle
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>52-year-old man</fact1> comes to the physician for the evaluation of a <fact2>painless right-sided scrotal swelling</fact2>. The swelling started <fact3>several weeks ago</fact3> but is not always present. Physical examination shows an <fact4>8-cm, soft, cystic nontender right-sided scrotal mass</fact4> that <fact5>transilluminates</fact5>. The mass does not increase in size on coughing and it is possible to <fact6>palpate normal tissue above the mass</fact6>. There are no <fact7>bowel sounds in the mass</fact7>, and it does not reduce when the patient is in a supine position. Examination of the <fact8>testis shows no abnormalities</fact8>. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the mass?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation, the key features include a <fact2>painless right-sided scrotal swelling</fact2> that is <fact4>8-cm, soft, cystic, and nontender</fact4>, and <fact5>transilluminates</fact5>, indicating that it is filled with fluid. Additionally, the ability to <fact6>palpate normal tissue above the mass</fact6> and the absence of <fact7>bowel sounds in the mass</fact7> help rule out certain conditions such as hernias. The fact that the <fact8>testis shows no abnormalities</fact8> also points away from testicular pathology. Given these characteristics, the most likely cause of the mass is an imbalance of fluid secretion and resorption by the tunica vaginalis, which is characteristic of a hydrocele. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive muscle weakness for five months. She feels that the muscles in her shoulders and hips have been getting weaker and sometimes feel sore. She now has difficulty getting up from chairs, climbing stairs, and combing her hair. She has also noticed new difficulty with swallowing solid foods, but has no trouble with liquids. She has a 5-year history of hyperlipidemia controlled with fluvastatin. Her maternal uncle died at age 26 from Duchenne's muscular dystrophy and her mother has Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Vital signs are within normal limits. Neurologic examination shows moderate weakness in the arm abductors and hip flexors bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13.7 g/dL
Leukocytes 11,200/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 33 mm/h
Serum
Creatine kinase 212 U/L
Lactate dehydrogenase 164 U/L
AST 34 U/L
ALT 35 U/L
Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?"
A) Intrafascicular infiltration on muscle biopsy
B) Inflammation of synovial spaces on ultrasound
C) Perifascicular and perivascular infiltration on muscle biopsy
D) Positive anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies
E) Dystrophin gene mutation on genetic analysis
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>47-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>progressive muscle weakness for five months</fact2>. She feels that the muscles in her <fact3>shoulders and hips have been getting weaker</fact3> and sometimes feel sore. She now has difficulty <fact4>getting up from chairs, climbing stairs, and combing her hair</fact4>. She has also noticed new difficulty with <fact5>swallowing solid foods, but has no trouble with liquids</fact5>. She has a <fact6>5-year history of hyperlipidemia controlled with fluvastatin</fact6>. Her <fact7>maternal uncle died at age 26 from Duchenne's muscular dystrophy</fact7> and her mother has Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Vital signs are within normal limits. Neurologic examination shows <fact8>moderate weakness in the arm abductors and hip flexors bilaterally</fact8>. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:
<fact9>Hemoglobin 13.7 g/dL</fact9>
<fact10>Leukocytes 11,200/mm3</fact10>
<fact11>Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 33 mm/h</fact11>
Serum
<fact12>Creatine kinase 212 U/L</fact12>
<fact13>Lactate dehydrogenase 164 U/L</fact13>
<fact14>AST 34 U/L</fact14>
<fact15>ALT 35 U/L</fact15>
Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

Answer:
Given the patient's symptoms of <fact2>progressive muscle weakness</fact2>, particularly in the <fact3>shoulders and hips</fact3>, and difficulty with <fact4>getting up from chairs, climbing stairs, and combing her hair</fact4>, along with the laboratory findings of elevated <fact12>creatine kinase</fact12> and <fact13>lactate dehydrogenase</fact13>, the most likely diagnosis is a form of muscular dystrophy. However, the patient's age and gender make Duchenne's muscular dystrophy, which affected her <fact7>maternal uncle</fact7>, less likely. The presence of <fact8>moderate weakness in the arm abductors and hip flexors bilaterally</fact8> and the absence of significant elevation in liver enzymes (<fact14>AST</fact14> and <fact15>ALT</fact15>) also support this diagnosis. Among the options provided, the finding that would most likely confirm the diagnosis is perifascicular and perivascular infiltration on muscle biopsy, which is characteristic of certain types of muscular dystrophy and myopathies. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 34-year-old patient is brought to the emergency room after a motor vehicle accident. An EKG shows sinus tachycardia and chest radiograph reveals an enlarged cardiac silhouette. While observing sinus tachycardia on the patient's telemetry, you note that the radial pulse cannot be palpated during inspiration. What should be the next step in management of this patient?
A) IV Heparin
B) Pericardiocentesis
C) Chest CT scan
D) Pericardial window
E) Insert chest tube
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>34-year-old patient</fact1> is brought to the emergency room after a <fact2>motor vehicle accident</fact2>. An <fact3>EKG shows sinus tachycardia</fact3> and <fact4>chest radiograph reveals an enlarged cardiac silhouette</fact4>. While observing <fact5>sinus tachycardia on the patient's telemetry</fact5>, you note that the <fact6>radial pulse cannot be palpated during inspiration</fact6>. What should be the next step in management of this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms, particularly the <fact6>radial pulse cannot be palpated during inspiration</fact6>, which is a classic sign of pulsus paradoxus, and the <fact4>enlarged cardiac silhouette</fact4> on chest radiograph, the most likely diagnosis is cardiac tamponade. Given this life-threatening condition, the next step in management should be to relieve the pressure on the heart by removing the accumulated fluid. Among the options provided, <fact7>pericardiocentesis</fact7> is the most appropriate immediate action to take. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 51-year-old Asian woman presents to her primary care provider with abdominal pain. On examination, she is found to have rebound tenderness in the lower right quadrant of her abdomen. Further workup suggests ovarian cancer, which is confirmed later in the week to be stage 4 with confirmed distant metastases in the lungs and brain. Which of the following routes describes the most likely lymphatic route for this malignancy to have metastasized to the brain?
A) Sentinel node - left lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - right bronchomediastinal trunk - right lymphatic duct - right subclavian vein - systemic circulation
B) Sentinel node - left lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - thoracic duct - left subclavian vein - systemic circulation
C) Sentinel node - right lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - right bronchomediastinal trunk - right lymphatic duct - right subclavian vein - systemic circulation
D) Sentinel node - right lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - thoracic duct - right subclavian vein - systemic circulation
E) Sentinel node - right lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - thoracic duct - left subclavian vein - systemic circulation
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>51-year-old Asian woman</fact1> presents to her primary care provider with <fact2>abdominal pain</fact2>. On examination, she is found to have <fact3>rebound tenderness in the lower right quadrant of her abdomen</fact3>. Further workup suggests <fact4>ovarian cancer</fact4>, which is confirmed later in the week to be <fact5>stage 4 with confirmed distant metastases in the lungs and brain</fact5>. Which of the following routes describes the most likely lymphatic route for this <fact6>malignancy to have metastasized to the brain</fact6>?

A) Sentinel node - left lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - right bronchomediastinal trunk - right lymphatic duct - right subclavian vein - systemic circulation
B) Sentinel node - left lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - thoracic duct - left subclavian vein - systemic circulation
C) Sentinel node - right lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - right bronchomediastinal trunk - right lymphatic duct - right subclavian vein - systemic circulation
D) Sentinel node - right lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - thoracic duct - right subclavian vein - systemic circulation
E) Sentinel node - right lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - thoracic duct - left subclavian vein - systemic circulation

Answer: 
Given the <fact1>51-year-old Asian woman's</fact1> diagnosis of <fact4>ovarian cancer</fact4> with <fact5>stage 4 metastases in the lungs and brain</fact5>, we need to consider the lymphatic drainage pathway that would most likely lead to brain metastasis. Ovarian cancer primarily drains into the lymphatic vessels that follow the ovarian arteries, which originate from the abdominal aorta below the renal arteries. These lymphatic vessels drain into the lumbar trunks. Since the cancer is located near the <fact3>lower right quadrant of her abdomen</fact3>, it would likely drain into the right lumbar trunk. From there, the lymphatic fluid would flow into the cisterna chyli, which is a dilated lymphatic vessel that serves as the origin of the thoracic duct. The thoracic duct then ascends through the thoracic cavity and empties into the left subclavian vein, allowing the cancer cells to enter the systemic circulation and potentially metastasize to the brain. Therefore, the most likely lymphatic route for this <fact6>malignancy to have metastasized to the brain</fact6> is option E.

question:
A 42-year-old man presents to a neurologist for evaluation of severe headache. He started experiencing episodic headaches and palpitations 3 months ago; however, he thought that these symptoms were simply related to the stress of moving and starting a new job. He has continued to experience these intermittent headaches and has also noticed that he sweats profusely during these episodes. On presentation his temperature is 99.1°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 163/112 mmHg, pulse is 112/min, and respirations are 15/min. Physical exam reveals pallor and perspiration but is otherwise unremarkable. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is produced by cells located in which region of the histology slide shown in figure A?
A) A
B) B
C) C
D) D
E) E
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>42-year-old man</fact1> presents to a neurologist for evaluation of <fact2>severe headache</fact2>. He started experiencing <fact3>episodic headaches and palpitations</fact3> 3 months ago; however, he thought that these symptoms were simply related to the stress of moving and starting a new job. He has continued to experience these <fact4>intermittent headaches</fact4> and has also noticed that he <fact5>sweats profusely during these episodes</fact5>. On presentation his <fact6>temperature is 99.1°F (37.3°C)</fact6>, <fact7>blood pressure is 163/112 mmHg</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 112/min</fact8>, and <fact9>respirations are 15/min</fact9>. Physical exam reveals <fact10>pallor and perspiration</fact10> but is otherwise unremarkable. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is produced by cells located in which region of the histology slide shown in figure A?

Answer: 
Given the patient's symptoms of <fact2>severe headache</fact2>, <fact3>episodic headaches and palpitations</fact3>, and <fact5>profuse sweating during episodes</fact5>, along with the findings of <fact7>elevated blood pressure</fact7> and <fact10>pallor and perspiration</fact10> on physical examination, the clinical presentation is highly suggestive of pheochromocytoma. Pheochromocytomas are tumors of the adrenal medulla that produce excess catecholamines, leading to these symptoms. The adrenal medulla is composed of chromaffin cells, which are responsible for the production of catecholamines. Therefore, the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is produced by cells located in the adrenal medulla. Unfortunately, without the actual figure A provided in the question, it's impossible to directly reference the region on the histology slide. However, based on the description, the answer would correspond to the region of the adrenal medulla, which is typically located in the central part of the adrenal gland.

question:
A 38-year-old woman presents with eye dryness and a foreign body sensation in the eyes. On physical examination, the oral cavity shows mucosal ulceration and atrophy. Biopsy of the lower lip shows marked lymphocytic infiltration of the minor salivary glands. Which of the following is most likely seen in this patient?
A) Anti-Sjögren's syndrome type B (SS-B) antibody
B) Anti-centromere antibody
C) Anti-Jo-1 antibody
D) Anti-Scl-70 antibodies
E) Anti-double stranded (-ds)DNA
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>38-year-old woman</fact1> presents with <fact2>eye dryness and a foreign body sensation in the eyes</fact2>. On physical examination, the oral cavity shows <fact3>mucosal ulceration and atrophy</fact3>. Biopsy of the lower lip shows <fact4>marked lymphocytic infiltration of the minor salivary glands</fact4>. Which of the following is most likely seen in this patient?

Answer: 
Analyzing the symptoms presented by the <fact1>38-year-old woman</fact1>, including <fact2>eye dryness and a foreign body sensation in the eyes</fact2> along with <fact3>mucosal ulceration and atrophy</fact3> in the oral cavity, suggests an autoimmune condition affecting the exocrine glands. The biopsy finding of <fact4>marked lymphocytic infiltration of the minor salivary glands</fact4> further supports this diagnosis, pointing towards Sjögren's syndrome. Sjögren's syndrome is characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of the exocrine glands, primarily the salivary and lacrimal glands, leading to symptoms of dry mouth (xerostomia) and dry eyes (xerophthalmia). Among the options provided, Anti-Sjögren's syndrome type B (SS-B) antibody is a specific autoantibody associated with Sjögren's syndrome. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department because she has a cord-like rash on her left calf that is red and painful to touch. She says that she has had multiple such lesions previously. Other medical history reveals that she has had 3 past spontaneous abortions at < 10 weeks of gestational age but has never been diagnosed with any diseases. She drinks socially but has never smoked or used drugs. She has never taken any medications except for over the counter analgesics and antipyretics. Physical exam shows that the cord-like lesion is tender, thick, and hardened on palpation. In addition, she has a lacy mottled violaceous rash on multiple extremities. Which of the following antibodies would most likely be found in this patient's blood?
A) Anti-cardiolipin
B) Anti-centromere
C) Anti-helicase
D) Anti-histone
E) Anti-ribonucleoprotein
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>32-year-old woman</fact1> presents to the emergency department because she has a <fact2>cord-like rash on her left calf that is red and painful to touch</fact2>. She says that she has had <fact3>multiple such lesions previously</fact3>. Other medical history reveals that she has had <fact4>3 past spontaneous abortions at < 10 weeks of gestational age</fact4> but has never been diagnosed with any diseases. She drinks socially but has never smoked or used drugs. She has never taken any medications except for over the counter analgesics and antipyretics. Physical exam shows that the <fact5>cord-like lesion is tender, thick, and hardened on palpation</fact5>. In addition, she has a <fact6>lacy mottled violaceous rash on multiple extremities</fact6>. Which of the following antibodies would most likely be found in this patient's blood?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's history of <fact4>3 past spontaneous abortions at < 10 weeks of gestational age</fact4> and the presence of a <fact2>cord-like rash on her left calf that is red and painful to touch</fact2>, along with <fact3>multiple such lesions previously</fact3>, it suggests a possible diagnosis of antiphospholipid syndrome. This condition is characterized by recurrent thrombosis and pregnancy complications, often associated with the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies. The physical exam findings of a <fact5>cord-like lesion</fact5> and a <fact6>lacy mottled violaceous rash on multiple extremities</fact6> further support this diagnosis, as they are indicative of livedo reticularis, a common skin manifestation in antiphospholipid syndrome. Among the options provided, anti-cardiolipin antibodies are a type of antiphospholipid antibody commonly found in patients with this syndrome. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
An 18-year-old patient is visiting the pediatrician with her mother for her annual exam before college starts. Her height and weight are appropriate for her age, and she is up to date on all her vaccinations and has no medical complaints. She is doing well in school and has a part-time job stocking shelves at a clothing store. She was offered a higher-paying job as a cashier at the store, but she declined. She is very shy and withdrawn with the physician. Afterwards, her mother asks to speak to the physician alone and expresses concern that her daughter is very socially isolated and feels lonely. She is also worried that her daughter is extremely sensitive to criticism, even from family. The daughter is interested in art and music, but hasn’t participated in any extracurriculars because she says that she is untalented and thinks nobody wants to hang out with her. When her mother has encouraged her to invite friends over, the daughter bursts into tears and says, “Nobody wants to be friends with me, I am too lame and ugly and I just know I’ll end up getting rejected.” Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the daughter’s behavior?
A) Schizotypal personality disorder
B) Generalized anxiety disorder
C) Avoidant personality disorder
D) Paranoid personality disorder
E) Dependent personality disorder
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
An <fact1>18-year-old patient</fact1> is visiting the pediatrician with her mother for her annual exam before college starts. Her <fact2>height and weight are appropriate for her age</fact2>, and she is up to date on all her vaccinations and has no medical complaints. She is doing well in school and has a <fact3>part-time job stocking shelves at a clothing store</fact3>. She was offered a <fact4>higher-paying job as a cashier at the store, but she declined</fact4>. She is very <fact5>shy and withdrawn with the physician</fact5>. Afterwards, her mother asks to speak to the physician alone and expresses concern that her daughter is very <fact6>socially isolated and feels lonely</fact6>. She is also worried that her daughter is extremely <fact7>sensitive to criticism, even from family</fact7>. The daughter is interested in <fact8>art and music, but hasn’t participated in any extracurriculars</fact8> because she says that she is <fact9>untalented and thinks nobody wants to hang out with her</fact9>. When her mother has encouraged her to invite friends over, the daughter <fact10>bursts into tears and says, “Nobody wants to be friends with me, I am too lame and ugly and I just know I’ll end up getting rejected”</fact10>. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the daughter’s behavior?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>18-year-old patient's</fact1> behavior, particularly her being very <fact5>shy and withdrawn with the physician</fact5>, and her mother's concerns about her being <fact6>socially isolated and feeling lonely</fact6>, it is clear that she struggles with social interactions. Additionally, her extreme <fact7>sensitivity to criticism, even from family</fact7>, and her negative self-perception, as evident from her statement <fact10>“Nobody wants to be friends with me, I am too lame and ugly and I just know I’ll end up getting rejected”</fact10>, point towards a deep-seated fear of rejection and criticism. Her decision to decline a <fact4>higher-paying job as a cashier at the store</fact4> and her lack of participation in <fact8>art and music extracurriculars</fact8> due to feeling <fact9>untalented</fact9> further support the notion that she avoids situations where she might be evaluated or rejected by others. These characteristics align with the diagnostic criteria for Avoidant Personality Disorder, which is characterized by pervasive feelings of social inadequacy, hypersensitivity to criticism or rejection, and avoidance of social interactions due to fear of criticism or rejection. Therefore, the most likely explanation for the daughter’s behavior is {C}.

question:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a sudden loss of consciousness. He has asthma and has been hospitalized multiple times. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is somnolent and diaphoretic. Serum studies show a glucose concentration of 22 mg/dL and a potassium concentration of 2.4 mEq/L. A dextrose infusion is administered, after which his glucose concentration normalizes and his symptoms improve. He is admitted to the hospital for further observation. Overnight, he has another episode of decreased consciousness. Serum studies taken during the episode show a glucose concentration of 19 mg/dL, an insulin concentration of 108 mIU/L (N=2.6–24.9), and a C-peptide concentration of 0.3 ng/mL (N = 0.8–3.1). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Malingering
B) Glucagonoma
C) Primary adrenal insufficiency
D) Conversion disorder
E) Factitious disorder imposed on another
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>5-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a <fact2>sudden loss of consciousness</fact2>. He has <fact3>asthma</fact3> and has been hospitalized multiple times. His mother has <fact4>type 2 diabetes mellitus</fact4>. He is <fact5>somnolent and diaphoretic</fact5>. Serum studies show a <fact6>glucose concentration of 22 mg/dL</fact6> and a <fact7>potassium concentration of 2.4 mEq/L</fact7>. A <fact8>dextrose infusion</fact8> is administered, after which his glucose concentration normalizes and his symptoms improve. He is admitted to the hospital for further observation. Overnight, he has another episode of <fact9>decreased consciousness</fact9>. Serum studies taken during the episode show a <fact10>glucose concentration of 19 mg/dL</fact10>, an <fact11>insulin concentration of 108 mIU/L</fact11> (N=2.6–24.9), and a <fact12>C-peptide concentration of 0.3 ng/mL</fact12> (N = 0.8–3.1). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Answer: 
Analyzing the situation, the <fact1>5-year-old boy</fact1> experienced a <fact2>sudden loss of consciousness</fact2> with a critically low <fact6>glucose concentration of 22 mg/dL</fact6> and a low <fact7>potassium concentration of 2.4 mEq/L</fact7>. The administration of a <fact8>dextrose infusion</fact8> improved his symptoms temporarily, but he had another episode of <fact9>decreased consciousness</fact9> with a similarly low <fact10>glucose concentration of 19 mg/dL</fact10>. Notably, during this episode, his <fact11>insulin concentration was elevated at 108 mIU/L</fact11>, while his <fact12>C-peptide concentration was low at 0.3 ng/mL</fact12>. This discrepancy between insulin and C-peptide levels is indicative of exogenous insulin administration, as C-peptide is a marker of endogenous insulin production. Given these findings and considering the mother's history of <fact4>type 2 diabetes mellitus</fact4>, which might provide access to insulin, the most likely diagnosis is factitious disorder imposed on another, where the mother is administering insulin to the child. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A laboratory primarily involved with studying cellular proofreading mechanisms is investigating the question of whether the ribosome can recognize a mischarged amino acid and still be incorporated into the growing peptide. In order to do so, they biochemically charge a Lys-tRNA with valine instead of lysine and insert the tRNA into the cell. They design an mRNA sequence that contains only codons for lysine. Which of the following will most likely occur?
A) The ribosome will recognize the mischarged tRNA and prevent its incorporation by removing the valine
B) The ribosome will recognize the inappropriately inserted valine residue and terminate protein translation
C) The mischarged tRNA with valine will be incorporated in the codons that specificy for lysine
D) The mischarged tRNA will be degraded by the proteasome
E) The mischarged tRNA will be removed by the lysyl-tRNA synthetase
answer:
Reformatted Question: A laboratory primarily involved with studying <fact1>cellular proofreading mechanisms</fact1> is investigating the question of whether the <fact2>ribosome can recognize a mischarged amino acid</fact2> and still be incorporated into the growing peptide. In order to do so, they biochemically charge a <fact3>Lys-tRNA with valine instead of lysine</fact3> and insert the tRNA into the cell. They design an <fact4>mRNA sequence that contains only codons for lysine</fact4>. Which of the following will most likely occur?

Answer: The <fact2>ribosome's ability to recognize a mischarged amino acid</fact2> is being tested in this experiment. Given that the <fact3>Lys-tRNA is charged with valine instead of lysine</fact3> and the <fact4>mRNA sequence contains only codons for lysine</fact4>, the most likely outcome is that the mischarged tRNA with valine will be incorporated into the codons that specify for lysine. This is because the ribosome primarily checks for correct codon-anticodon pairing, not the actual amino acid attached to the tRNA. Therefore, the correct answer is {C}.

question:
A 70-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of back pain. For the past six days, she has had a burning pain in her upper right back and chest. She cannot recall any recent injury and has no prior history of back pain. She has a history of hypertension and gastroesophageal reflux. The patient volunteers at an animal shelter three times a week. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications include ramipril and pantoprazole. The patient appears healthy and well nourished. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.42°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 145/92 mm Hg. Examination shows a long erythematous rash covered with multiple clear vesicles and crusty lesions extending from her back to below her right breast. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of the disease?
A) Viral reactivation in dorsal root ganglia
B) IgA deposits in the upper dermis
C) Bacterial lymphatic infection of the epidermis
D) Infestation with bloodsucking parasites
E) Brown recluse spider envenomation
answer:
