Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of these findings?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms, including <fact2>altered mental status</fact2>, <fact3>confusion</fact3>, <fact7>lethargy</fact7>, and <fact12>weakness in the lower extremities with absent deep tendon reflexes</fact12>, along with the <fact8>low rectal temperature</fact8> and <fact13>dilated pupils poorly reactive to light</fact13>, it is suggestive of an antipsychotic medication side effect, particularly hypothermia and anticholinergic toxicity. Given the patient's history of <fact5>schizoaffective disorder</fact5> and the recent initiation of a <fact6>new drug</fact6>, the most likely cause is an antipsychotic medication. Among the options, Fluphenazine is an antipsychotic that can cause such side effects. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 28-year-old man reports to his physician that he is having second thoughts about his long-term compatibility with his wife ever since they relocated to a new city. He admits that he has noticed himself flirting with some of the female co-workers at his new workplace. When he goes on a dinner date with his wife after work one evening, he accuses her of giving their waiter flirtatious looks and asks her whether she has been cheating on him or trying to spend time with other men. The man’s actions are most consistent with which of the following psychological defense mechanisms?
A) Displacement
B) Dissociation
C) Projection
D) Reaction formation
E) Repression
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>28-year-old man</fact1> reports to his physician that he is having <fact2>second thoughts about his long-term compatibility with his wife</fact2> ever since they relocated to a new city. He admits that he has noticed himself <fact3>flirting with some of the female co-workers at his new workplace</fact3>. When he goes on a dinner date with his wife after work one evening, he accuses her of giving their waiter <fact4>flirtatious looks</fact4> and asks her whether she has been <fact5>cheating on him or trying to spend time with other men</fact5>. The man’s actions are most consistent with which of the following psychological defense mechanisms?

Answer: 
The man's actions are most consistent with {C} Projection. This defense mechanism involves attributing one's unacceptable thoughts or feelings to someone else. In this case, the <fact1>28-year-old man</fact1> is experiencing <fact2>second thoughts about his long-term compatibility with his wife</fact2> and has found himself <fact3>flirting with some of the female co-workers at his new workplace</fact3>, indicating potential feelings of attraction towards others. However, instead of acknowledging these feelings, he accuses his wife of giving their waiter <fact4>flirtatious looks</fact4> and questions whether she has been <fact5>cheating on him or trying to spend time with other men</fact5>, thereby projecting his own feelings onto her. This behavior is a classic example of projection, where an individual attributes their own undesirable feelings or impulses to someone else, often as a way to avoid confronting or dealing with those feelings within themselves.

question:
A 25-year-old woman presents to her physician with a four month history of fatigue and weakness. The weakness has been progressive to the point where she cannot climb stairs and stand from a sitting position. She has only had one menstrual period in the last four months and has never been pregnant. She smokes a pack of cigarettes every day and does not take any medications. Her temperature is 98°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 15/min. She is obese with a significant pannus. Abdominal striae are present. Her laboratory workup is notable for the following:

Serum:
Na+: 142 mEq/L
Cl-: 102 mEq/L
K+: 3.9 mEq/L
HCO3-: 25 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Glucose: 314 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
Ca2+: 10.1 mg/dL
AST: 9 U/L
ALT: 8 U/L
24-hour urinary cortisol: 470 µg (< 300 µg)
Serum cortisol 30 µg/mL (5-23 µg/dL)
Serum adrenocorticotropin-releasing hormone (ACTH) 2 pg/mL (> 5 pg/mL)

A 48-hour high dose dexamethasone suppression trial shows that her serum cortisol levels do not decrease. What is the best next step in management?
A) MRI of the adrenal glands
B) MRI of the chest
C) MRI of the pituitary gland
D) Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
E) Inferior petrosal sinus sampling
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>25-year-old woman</fact1> presents to her physician with a <fact2>four month history of fatigue and weakness</fact2>. The weakness has been progressive to the point where she cannot climb stairs and stand from a sitting position. She has only had one menstrual period in the last four months and has never been pregnant. She smokes a pack of cigarettes every day and does not take any medications. Her <fact3>temperature is 98°F (36.7°C)</fact3>, <fact4>blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg</fact4>, <fact5>pulse is 70/min</fact5>, and <fact6>respirations are 15/min</fact6>. She is obese with a significant pannus. Abdominal striae are present. Her laboratory workup is notable for the following:

Serum:
<fact7>Na+: 142 mEq/L</fact7>
<fact8>Cl-: 102 mEq/L</fact8>
<fact9>K+: 3.9 mEq/L</fact9>
<fact10>HCO3-: 25 mEq/L</fact10>
<fact11>BUN: 20 mg/dL</fact11>
<fact12>Glucose: 314 mg/dL</fact12>
<fact13>Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL</fact13>
<fact14>Ca2+: 10.1 mg/dL</fact14>
<fact15>AST: 9 U/L</fact15>
<fact16>ALT: 8 U/L</fact16>
<fact17>24-hour urinary cortisol: 470 µg (< 300 µg)</fact17>
<fact18>Serum cortisol 30 µg/mL (5-23 µg/dL)</fact18>
<fact19>Serum adrenocorticotropin-releasing hormone (ACTH) 2 pg/mL (> 5 pg/mL)</fact19>

A <fact20>48-hour high dose dexamethasone suppression trial</fact20> shows that her <fact21>serum cortisol levels do not decrease</fact21>. What is the best next step in management?

Answer:
Given the patient's <fact2>four month history of fatigue and weakness</fact2>, along with the laboratory findings of <fact17>elevated 24-hour urinary cortisol</fact17> and <fact18>elevated serum cortisol</fact18>, the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is strongly suggested. The <fact20>48-hour high dose dexamethasone suppression trial</fact20> showing that her <fact21>serum cortisol levels do not decrease</fact21> further supports this diagnosis and indicates that the cause is likely an adrenal tumor, as pituitary ACTH secretion would typically be suppressed by high-dose dexamethasone. Additionally, the low <fact19>serum adrenocorticotropin-releasing hormone (ACTH)</fact19> level points towards an adrenal source of the excess cortisol. Therefore, the best next step in management is to perform an MRI of the adrenal glands to identify any potential tumors. The answer is {A}.

question:
A 35-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency room with unilateral leg swelling. She reports that she developed painful left-sided leg swelling and redness earlier in the day. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. She denies any recent prolonged travel. She experienced a similar episode affecting the opposite leg one year ago and was diagnosed with a thrombus in the right femoral vein. On examination, the left leg is erythematous and swollen. Passive dorsiflexion of the left ankle elicits pain in the left calf. Ultrasound of the leg reveals a thrombus in the left popliteal vein. A genetic workup reveals that she has an inherited condition. What is the most likely pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?
A) Elevated serum homocysteine
B) Thrombin inhibitor deficiency
C) Deficiency in protein C
D) Auto-antibodies directed against phospholipids
E) Resistance to clotting factor degradation
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>35-year-old Caucasian female</fact1> presents to the emergency room with <fact2>unilateral leg swelling</fact2>. She reports that she developed <fact3>painful left-sided leg swelling and redness</fact3> earlier in the day. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. She denies any recent <fact4>prolonged travel</fact4>. She experienced a similar episode affecting the opposite leg one year ago and was diagnosed with a <fact5>thrombus in the right femoral vein</fact5>. On examination, the left leg is <fact6>erythematous and swollen</fact6>. <fact7>Passive dorsiflexion of the left ankle elicits pain in the left calf</fact7>. <fact8>Ultrasound of the leg reveals a thrombus in the left popliteal vein</fact8>. A genetic workup reveals that she has an <fact9>inherited condition</fact9>. What is the most likely pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact9>inherited condition</fact9> and the recurrence of a similar episode (a <fact5>thrombus in the right femoral vein</fact5> one year ago and now a <fact8>thrombus in the left popliteal vein</fact8>), it suggests a genetic predisposition to thrombosis. Among the options provided, a deficiency in protein C, which is a natural anticoagulant, would increase the risk of developing thrombi. This condition is known as Protein C deficiency, an inherited disorder that increases the risk of blood clots. The patient's presentation of <fact2>unilateral leg swelling</fact2>, <fact3>painful left-sided leg swelling and redness</fact3>, and a positive Homan's sign (<fact7>passive dorsiflexion of the left ankle elicits pain in the left calf</fact7>) further supports the diagnosis of a deep vein thrombosis. Therefore, the most likely pathophysiology of this patient’s condition is a deficiency in protein C, which is option {C}.

question:
A 60-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of increasing difficulty in breathing with a productive cough. He reports having shortness of breath over the last 6 months, but he has felt worse since he contracted a cold that has been traveling around his office. Today, he reports body aches, headache, and fever along with this chronic cough. His past medical history is significant for prediabetes, which he controls with exercise and diet. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history. His blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, pulse rate is 90/min, temperature is 36.9°C (98.5°F), and respiratory rate is 18/min. Physical examination reveals diminished breath sounds bilateral, a barrel-shaped chest, and measured breathing through pursed lips. A chest X-ray reveals a flattened diaphragm and no signs of consolidation. Pulmonary function testing reveals FEV1/FVC ratio of 60%. Arterial blood gases (ABG) of this patient are most likely to reveal which of the following?
A) Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis
B) Primary respiratory acidosis
C) Primary respiratory alkalosis
D) Compensatory respiratory acidosis
E) Anion gap metabolic acidosis with respiratory alkalosis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>60-year-old man</fact1> presents with a <fact2>2-day history of increasing difficulty in breathing</fact2> with a productive cough. He reports having <fact3>shortness of breath over the last 6 months</fact3>, but he has felt worse since he contracted a cold that has been traveling around his office. Today, he reports <fact4>body aches, headache, and fever</fact4> along with this chronic cough. His past medical history is significant for <fact5>prediabetes</fact5>, which he controls with exercise and diet. He has a <fact6>30-pack-year smoking history</fact6>. His <fact7>blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg</fact7>, <fact8>pulse rate is 90/min</fact8>, <fact9>temperature is 36.9°C (98.5°F)</fact9>, and <fact10>respiratory rate is 18/min</fact10>. Physical examination reveals <fact11>diminished breath sounds bilateral</fact11>, a <fact12>barrel-shaped chest</fact12>, and measured breathing through pursed lips. A <fact13>chest X-ray reveals a flattened diaphragm</fact13> and no signs of consolidation. <fact14>Pulmonary function testing reveals FEV1/FVC ratio of 60%</fact14>. Arterial blood gases (ABG) of this patient are most likely to reveal which of the following?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact6>30-pack-year smoking history</fact6> and the presence of a <fact12>barrel-shaped chest</fact12> and <fact13>flattened diaphragm on chest X-ray</fact13>, it is likely that the patient has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The <fact14>FEV1/FVC ratio of 60%</fact14> from pulmonary function testing further supports this diagnosis, indicating an obstructive pattern. In COPD, there is often a degree of carbon dioxide retention leading to a primary respiratory acidosis. Therefore, the most likely finding on arterial blood gases (ABG) would be a primary respiratory acidosis. The answer is {B}.

question:
A 61-year-old man presents to his primary care provider complaining of abdominal pain and constipation. He reports a 4-day history of steady right lower quadrant pain. He has had one small bowel movement in 4 days. Normally he has a bowel movement once a day. His medical history is notable for poorly controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He takes enalapril, hydrochlorothiazide, aspirin, and atorvastatin. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history and drinks 3-4 beers per day. His diet consists primarily of fast food. His temperature is 101.8°F (38.8°C), blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 16/min. A review of the patient’s medical record reveals colonoscopy results from 1 year ago. Relevant findings included multiple small, pedunculated polyps which were removed, multiple colonic mucosal outpouchings, and no other masses. This patient’s condition is most strongly associated with which of the following disorders?
A) Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency
B) Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disorder
C) Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
D) Goodpasture syndrome
E) Menetrier disease
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>61-year-old man</fact1> presents to his primary care provider complaining of <fact2>abdominal pain and constipation</fact2>. He reports a <fact3>4-day history of steady right lower quadrant pain</fact3>. He has had one small bowel movement in 4 days. Normally he has a bowel movement once a day. His medical history is notable for <fact4>poorly controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia</fact4>. He takes enalapril, hydrochlorothiazide, aspirin, and atorvastatin. He has a <fact5>40 pack-year smoking history</fact5> and drinks 3-4 beers per day. His diet consists primarily of fast food. His <fact6>temperature is 101.8°F (38.8°C)</fact6>, <fact7>blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 90/min</fact8>, and <fact9>respirations are 16/min</fact9>. A review of the patient’s medical record reveals <fact10>colonoscopy results from 1 year ago</fact10>. Relevant findings included <fact11>multiple small, pedunculated polyps which were removed</fact11>, <fact12>multiple colonic mucosal outpouchings</fact12>, and no other masses. This patient’s condition is most strongly associated with which of the following disorders?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>abdominal pain and constipation</fact2> and the findings from the <fact10>colonoscopy results from 1 year ago</fact10>, which included <fact12>multiple colonic mucosal outpouchings</fact12>, the condition is most likely diverticulitis. Diverticulitis is strongly associated with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, a genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissue. The presence of <fact12>multiple colonic mucosal outpouchings</fact12> is indicative of diverticulosis, and the patient's symptoms suggest an inflammatory complication, which is consistent with diverticulitis. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 25-year-old male involved in a knife fight presents with a penetrating wound to the chest. The patient is unconscious and cannot provide any further history. Vitals show a temperature of 37-0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure of 85/55 mm Hg, pulse of 115/min, respirations of 19/min, and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is diaphoretic and unresponsive. Extremities are pale and cool. There is a 3-inch long penetrating wound between the 3rd and 4th intercostal space on the left side of the chest, which is bleeding profusely. Transthoracic echocardiography reveals a full thickness penetrating injury to the right ventricular free wall. There are no apparent injuries to any coronary arteries or major branches. The patient is intubated and aggressive fluid resuscitation is initiated, including a blood transfusion. Which of the following is the best definitive surgical approach to take in this patient?
A) Immediate cardiac transplant
B) Watchful waiting while resuscitative fluids are initiated
C) Interrupted 2-0 polypropylene suture with supporting pledgets
D) Needle thoracostomy over the 2nd intercostal space
E) Surgical adhesive glue
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>25-year-old male</fact1> involved in a knife fight presents with a <fact2>penetrating wound to the chest</fact2>. The patient is unconscious and cannot provide any further history. Vitals show a <fact3>temperature of 37-0°C (98.6°F)</fact3>, <fact4>blood pressure of 85/55 mm Hg</fact4>, <fact5>pulse of 115/min</fact5>, <fact6>respirations of 19/min</fact6>, and <fact7>oxygen saturation of 92% on room air</fact7>. On physical examination, the patient is <fact8>diaphoretic and unresponsive</fact8>. Extremities are <fact9>pale and cool</fact9>. There is a <fact10>3-inch long penetrating wound between the 3rd and 4th intercostal space on the left side of the chest</fact10>, which is <fact11>bleeding profusely</fact11>. <fact12>Transthoracic echocardiography reveals a full thickness penetrating injury to the right ventricular free wall</fact12>. There are no apparent injuries to any <fact13>coronary arteries or major branches</fact13>. The patient is <fact14>intubated and aggressive fluid resuscitation is initiated, including a blood transfusion</fact14>. Which of the following is the best definitive surgical approach to take in this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact2>penetrating wound to the chest</fact2> with a <fact10>3-inch long penetrating wound between the 3rd and 4th intercostal space on the left side of the chest</fact10> that is <fact11>bleeding profusely</fact11>, along with the <fact12>transthoracic echocardiography revealing a full thickness penetrating injury to the right ventricular free wall</fact12>, a prompt and effective surgical intervention is necessary to repair the cardiac injury. Given that there are no apparent injuries to any <fact13>coronary arteries or major branches</fact13>, a direct repair of the ventricular free wall is feasible. Among the provided options, the use of <fact15>interrupted 2-0 polypropylene suture with supporting pledgets</fact15> is a well-established technique for repairing cardiac lacerations, offering a secure and durable closure. Therefore, the best definitive surgical approach for this patient is option {C}.

question:
A 76-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine examination. She has a history of hypertension well controlled with diet and exercise. She has no history of smoking or illicit drug use. She walks one mile daily. Her pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 119/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. When compared to a healthy 20-year-old woman, which of the following changes in respiratory function is most likely present in this patient?
A) Increased lung compliance
B) Increased vital capacity
C) Decreased residual volume
D) Increased chest wall compliance
E) Decreased A-a gradient
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>76-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician for a routine examination. She has a history of <fact2>hypertension well controlled with diet and exercise</fact2>. She has no history of <fact3>smoking or illicit drug use</fact3>. She <fact4>walks one mile daily</fact4>. Her <fact5>pulse is 68/min</fact5>, <fact6>respirations are 16/min</fact6>, and <fact7>blood pressure is 119/76 mm Hg</fact7>. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. When compared to a healthy <fact8>20-year-old woman</fact8>, which of the following changes in respiratory function is most likely present in this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's age, <fact1>76-year-old woman</fact1>, and comparing her to a healthy <fact8>20-year-old woman</fact8>, it is expected that her lung function would have undergone changes associated with aging. Among the options provided, the most likely change in respiratory function due to aging is an increase in lung compliance. This is because, with age, the elastic recoil of the lungs decreases, leading to an increase in lung compliance. Although she has a history of <fact2>hypertension well controlled with diet and exercise</fact2> and engages in physical activity by <fact4>walking one mile daily</fact4>, these factors do not directly influence the age-related changes in lung compliance. Her <fact5>pulse</fact5>, <fact6>respirations</fact6>, and <fact7>blood pressure</fact7> are all within normal limits, which further supports that the primary factor influencing her lung function is age. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, breast tenderness, increased urinary frequency, and intermittent nausea for 2 weeks. Her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. She has a history of a seizure disorder treated with carbamazepine. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is positive. The child is at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?
A) Renal dysplasia
B) Meningocele
C) Teeth discoloration
D) Sensorineural hearing loss
E) Vaginal clear cell carcinoma
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>32-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>fatigue, breast tenderness, increased urinary frequency, and intermittent nausea</fact2> for 2 weeks. Her last menstrual period was <fact3>7 weeks ago</fact3>. She has a history of a <fact4>seizure disorder</fact4> treated with <fact5>carbamazepine</fact5>. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A <fact6>urine pregnancy test is positive</fact6>. The child is at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>32-year-old woman</fact1> is pregnant, as indicated by the <fact6>positive urine pregnancy test</fact6>, and has a history of a <fact4>seizure disorder</fact4> treated with <fact5>carbamazepine</fact5>, it is essential to evaluate the potential risks of this medication on the fetus. Carbamazepine is known to be teratogenic, particularly concerning neural tube defects. Among the options provided, the child is at greatest risk of developing a <fact7>meningocele</fact7>, which is a type of neural tube defect. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 24-year-old man with chronic back pain comes to the physician to establish care after moving to Florida. He complains of anxiety, nausea, abdominal cramping, vomiting, and diarrhea for three days. He denies smoking, drinking alcohol, and using illicit drugs. He appears restless. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 150/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dilated pupils, diaphoresis, and piloerection. His abdominal exam shows diffuse mild tenderness. There is no rebound tenderness or guarding. His hemoglobin concentration is 14.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8,000/mm, and platelet count is 250,000/mm3; serum studies and urinalysis show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
A) Lorazepam
B) Naltrexone
C) Methadone
D) Morphine
E) Naloxone
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>24-year-old man</fact1> with <fact2>chronic back pain</fact2> comes to the physician to establish care after moving to Florida. He complains of <fact3>anxiety, nausea, abdominal cramping, vomiting, and diarrhea</fact3> for three days. He denies <fact4>smoking, drinking alcohol, and using illicit drugs</fact4>. He appears <fact5>restless</fact5>. His <fact6>temperature is 37°C (98.6°F)</fact6>, <fact7>pulse is 110/min</fact7>, and <fact8>blood pressure is 150/86 mm Hg</fact8>. Physical examination shows <fact9>dilated pupils, diaphoresis, and piloerection</fact9>. His abdominal exam shows <fact10>diffuse mild tenderness</fact10>. There is no <fact11>rebound tenderness or guarding</fact11>. His <fact12>hemoglobin concentration is 14.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8,000/mm, and platelet count is 250,000/mm3</fact12>; <fact13>serum studies and urinalysis show no abnormalities</fact13>. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact3>anxiety, nausea, abdominal cramping, vomiting, and diarrhea</fact3>, along with <fact9>dilated pupils, diaphoresis, and piloerection</fact9> on physical examination, it is suggestive of opioid withdrawal. The patient's denial of <fact4>smoking, drinking alcohol, and using illicit drugs</fact4> does not rule out prescription opioid use given his history of <fact2>chronic back pain</fact2>. The most appropriate pharmacotherapy for managing opioid withdrawal symptoms is an opioid agonist or partial agonist. Among the options provided, methadone is an opioid agonist commonly used for opioid detoxification and maintenance therapy. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 35-year-old man visits your office for his annual health checkup. He was diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder 6 months ago, which is being treated with citalopram. He comments that his symptoms have improved since initiating the prescribed therapy; however, in the past 2 months, he has been unable to have sexual intercourse due to weak tumescence and low libido. His blood pressure is 122/74 mm Hg, heart rate is 75/min, and respiratory rate is 16/min. Physical examination reveals regular heart and lung sounds. What is the appropriate step in the management of this patient?
A) Lowering citalopram dose
B) Addition of bupropion
C) Switch to fluoxetine
D) Addition of sildenafil
E) Switch to selegiline
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>35-year-old man</fact1> visits your office for his annual health checkup. He was diagnosed with <fact2>generalized anxiety disorder</fact2> 6 months ago, which is being treated with <fact3>citalopram</fact3>. He comments that his symptoms have improved since initiating the prescribed therapy; however, in the past <fact4>2 months</fact4>, he has been unable to have sexual intercourse due to <fact5>weak tumescence and low libido</fact5>. His <fact6>blood pressure is 122/74 mm Hg</fact6>, <fact7>heart rate is 75/min</fact7>, and <fact8>respiratory rate is 16/min</fact8>. Physical examination reveals regular <fact9>heart and lung sounds</fact9>. What is the appropriate step in the management of this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact2>generalized anxiety disorder</fact2> has improved with <fact3>citalopram</fact3>, but he is now experiencing <fact5>weak tumescence and low libido</fact5>, a common side effect of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) like citalopram, the best course of action would be to address this side effect directly. Since his <fact6>blood pressure</fact6>, <fact7>heart rate</fact7>, and <fact8>respiratory rate</fact8> are all within normal limits and his physical examination is unremarkable with regular <fact9>heart and lung sounds</fact9>, there's no immediate indication to change his primary treatment due to other adverse effects. Among the options provided, the addition of <fact10>sildenafil</fact10>, a phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor, is specifically targeted at treating erectile dysfunction, which aligns with his complaint of <fact5>weak tumescence</fact5>. Therefore, the appropriate step in the management of this patient is the addition of sildenafil, option {D}.

question:
A 63-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for follow-up. He reports a slow and steady weight gain of 6 pounds over the past 6 months, despite attempts to control his diet and increase his level of exercise. His medications include pravastatin, lisinopril, and hydrochlorothiazide. On exam, his vital signs are stable. He is obese (BMI 32), and his waist circumference is 43 inches. His physician is concerned about an abnormal fasting blood glucose and dyslipidemia. On further work-up with oral glucose tolerance test, the patient is diagnosed with diabetes. Which of the following associations is consistent with this patient’s most likely form of diabetes?
A) Strong HLA class II gene makeup
B) Pancreatic islet cell amyloid deposition
C) Pancreatic islet cell leukocyte infiltration
D) Auto-antibodies against pancreatic islet cell antigens
E) Unrelated to his abdominal obesity
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>63-year-old man</fact1> presents to his primary care physician for follow-up. He reports a <fact2>slow and steady weight gain of 6 pounds over the past 6 months</fact2>, despite attempts to control his <fact3>diet</fact3> and increase his level of <fact4>exercise</fact4>. His medications include <fact5>pravastatin, lisinopril, and hydrochlorothiazide</fact5>. On exam, his <fact6>vital signs are stable</fact6>. He is <fact7>obese (BMI 32)</fact7>, and his <fact8>waist circumference is 43 inches</fact8>. His physician is concerned about an <fact9>abnormal fasting blood glucose</fact9> and <fact10>dyslipidemia</fact10>. On further work-up with <fact11>oral glucose tolerance test</fact11>, the patient is diagnosed with <fact12>diabetes</fact12>. Which of the following associations is consistent with this patient’s most likely form of <fact12>diabetes</fact12>?

A) Strong HLA class II gene makeup
B) Pancreatic islet cell amyloid deposition
C) Pancreatic islet cell leukocyte infiltration
D) Auto-antibodies against pancreatic islet cell antigens
E) Unrelated to his abdominal obesity

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact7>obesity (BMI 32)</fact7> and <fact8>waist circumference of 43 inches</fact8>, along with the presence of <fact9>abnormal fasting blood glucose</fact9> and <fact10>dyslipidemia</fact10>, the most likely form of <fact12>diabetes</fact12> in this patient is type 2 diabetes. Type 2 diabetes is strongly associated with <fact7>obesity</fact7>, particularly central or abdominal obesity, as indicated by the patient's <fact8>waist circumference</fact8>. Among the options provided, pancreatic islet cell amyloid deposition is a characteristic feature of type 2 diabetes. Therefore, the correct answer is {B}.

question:
Patients with the diagnosis of sickle cell anemia make a specific type of hemoglobin known as HgbS. This mutation results in the sickling of their red blood cells when exposed to inciting factors such as hypoxic conditions. Patients are often treated with hydroxyurea, which has which of the following direct effects on their hemoglobin physiology?
A) Increases oxygen carrying capacity of hemoglobin
B) Decreases oxygen carrying capacity of hemoglobin
C) Increases levels of fetal hemoglobin (HgbF)
D) Decreases levels of HgbS
E) Decreases levels of fetal hemoglobin (HgbF)
answer:
Reformatted Question: Patients with the diagnosis of <fact1>sickle cell anemia</fact1> make a specific type of hemoglobin known as <fact2>HgbS</fact2>. This mutation results in the <fact3>sickling of their red blood cells</fact3> when exposed to inciting factors such as <fact4>hypoxic conditions</fact4>. Patients are often treated with <fact5>hydroxyurea</fact5>, which has which of the following direct effects on their hemoglobin physiology?

Answer: Analyzing the information provided, patients with <fact1>sickle cell anemia</fact1> are often treated with <fact5>hydroxyurea</fact5> to manage their condition. The direct effect of <fact5>hydroxyurea</fact5> on their hemoglobin physiology is to increase levels of <fact6>fetal hemoglobin (HgbF)</fact6>, which is not explicitly mentioned in the question but is a known effect of the treatment. Increasing <fact6>HgbF</fact6> helps to reduce the occurrence of <fact3>sickling of their red blood cells</fact3> by diluting the concentration of <fact2>HgbS</fact2>. Therefore, the correct answer is {C}.

question:
A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of persistent bleeding from his nose over the past hour. The bleeding started spontaneously. He has no history of a similar episode. He takes no medications. There is no history of abnormal bleeding in the family. His vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, he is pressing a gauze against his left nostril while hyperextending his head. The gauze is stained with blood and upon withdrawal of the gauze blood slowly drips out of his left nostrils. There is no bleeding from the right nostril. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial therapy?
A) Anterior packing and topical antibiotics
B) Oxymetazoline nasal spray
C) Placement of an epinephrine gauze in the left nostril
D) Silver nitrate cauterization of the bleeding vessel and surrounding vessels
E) Squeezing the nostrils manually for 10 minutes with the head elevated
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>12-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of <fact2>persistent bleeding from his nose</fact2> over the past hour. The <fact3>bleeding started spontaneously</fact3>. He has no history of a similar episode. He takes no medications. There is no history of <fact4>abnormal bleeding in the family</fact4>. His <fact5>vital signs are within normal limits</fact5>. On examination, he is pressing a gauze against his left nostril while <fact6>hyperextending his head</fact6>. The gauze is stained with blood and upon withdrawal of the gauze <fact7>blood slowly drips out of his left nostrils</fact7>. There is no bleeding from the right nostril. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial therapy?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>12-year-old boy</fact1> is experiencing <fact2>persistent bleeding from his nose</fact2> with no history of <fact4>abnormal bleeding in the family</fact4> and has <fact5>vital signs within normal limits</fact5>, the most appropriate initial therapy should focus on controlling the bleeding. Since the <fact7>blood slowly drips out of his left nostrils</fact7> and he is already <fact6>hyperextending his head</fact6>, which is a common first aid measure to reduce bleeding, the next step would be to apply a topical agent to help constrict the nasal vessels. Oxymetazoline nasal spray is a common and effective agent for this purpose. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 23-year-old man presents with swelling of the left knee. He noticed the swelling a day ago while preparing for the college basketball game. He has had approximately 10 different sexual partners in the past 3 months. Synovial fluid tap shows a WBC count of 90,000 cells/mm3. What is the mechanism of action of the drug which is indicated for the treatment of this patient’s most likely condition?
A) Metabolic inhibitor
B) Cell wall inhibitor
C) Neutrophil migration inhibitor
D) Prostaglandin inhibitor
E) Uric acid synthesis inhibitor
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>23-year-old man</fact1> presents with <fact2>swelling of the left knee</fact2>. He noticed the <fact2>swelling</fact2> a day ago while preparing for the college basketball game. He has had approximately <fact3>10 different sexual partners in the past 3 months</fact3>. <fact4>Synovial fluid tap</fact4> shows a <fact5>WBC count of 90,000 cells/mm3</fact5>. What is the mechanism of action of the drug which is indicated for the treatment of this patient’s most likely condition?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation, particularly the <fact2>swelling of the left knee</fact2> and the significantly elevated <fact5>WBC count of 90,000 cells/mm3</fact5> from the <fact4>synovial fluid tap</fact4>, along with the history of having <fact3>10 different sexual partners in the past 3 months</fact3>, the most likely condition is septic arthritis, likely caused by a sexually transmitted infection such as Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The treatment for septic arthritis typically involves antibiotics that can effectively target the causative pathogen. Among the options provided, the mechanism of action most relevant to treating bacterial infections is a cell wall inhibitor, which is how many antibiotics, including those used to treat gonococcal infections, work. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 27-year-old female presents to her physician with a palpable thyroid nodule. Iodine uptake testing shows that the nodule has decreased iodine uptake compared with the rest of the thyroid gland. A fine-needle aspiration is performed and the physician calls telling the patient that she has a neoplasm of the thyroid. Which of the following diagnoses is the most likely?
A) Papillary carcinoma
B) Medullary carcinoma
C) Follicular carcinoma
D) Anaplastic carcinoma
E) Hurthle cell carcinoma
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>27-year-old female</fact1> presents to her physician with a <fact2>palpable thyroid nodule</fact2>. <fact3>Iodine uptake testing</fact3> shows that the nodule has <fact4>decreased iodine uptake</fact4> compared with the rest of the thyroid gland. A <fact5>fine-needle aspiration</fact5> is performed and the physician calls telling the patient that she has a <fact6>neoplasm of the thyroid</fact6>. Which of the following diagnoses is the most likely?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation with a <fact2>palpable thyroid nodule</fact2> and the results of the <fact3>iodine uptake testing</fact3> showing <fact4>decreased iodine uptake</fact4>, this pattern is typically seen in thyroid neoplasms that do not concentrate iodine as well as the surrounding thyroid tissue. Among the options provided, follicular carcinoma is known for having decreased iodine uptake compared to the rest of the thyroid gland. Additionally, the diagnosis of a <fact6>neoplasm of the thyroid</fact6> via <fact5>fine-needle aspiration</fact5> supports this conclusion. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is {C}.

question:
A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain and vomiting for 8 hours. He has had around 3–4 episodes of greenish colored vomit during this period. He has major depressive disorder with psychosis. His mother has Graves' disease. Current medications include sertraline and haloperidol. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg. He is diagnosed with acute appendicitis and is taken to the operating room for an emergency laparoscopic appendectomy. The appendix is gangrenous and perforated with purulent fluid in the pelvis. Just after the appendiceal base is ligated, the patient shows muscle rigidity and profuse diaphoresis. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 130/min, and blood pressure is 146/70 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The end-tidal CO2 is 85 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
A) Propranolol
B) Dantrolene
C) Bromocriptine
D) Cyproheptadine
E) Surgical embolectomy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>15-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to the emergency department because of <fact2>severe abdominal pain and vomiting</fact2> for 8 hours. He has had around 3–4 episodes of <fact3>greenish colored vomit</fact3> during this period. He has <fact4>major depressive disorder with psychosis</fact4>. His mother has <fact5>Graves' disease</fact5>. Current medications include <fact6>sertraline and haloperidol</fact6>. He appears uncomfortable. His <fact7>temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F)</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 87/min</fact8>, and <fact9>blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg</fact9>. He is diagnosed with <fact10>acute appendicitis</fact10> and is taken to the operating room for an emergency <fact11>laparoscopic appendectomy</fact11>. The <fact12>appendix is gangrenous and perforated</fact12> with <fact13>purulent fluid in the pelvis</fact13>. Just after the <fact14>appendiceal base is ligated</fact14>, the patient shows <fact15>muscle rigidity and profuse diaphoresis</fact15>. His <fact16>temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F)</fact16>, <fact17>pulse is 130/min</fact17>, and <fact18>blood pressure is 146/70 mm Hg</fact18>. The <fact19>pupils are equal and reactive to light</fact19>. The <fact20>end-tidal CO2 is 85 mm Hg</fact20>. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact15>muscle rigidity and profuse diaphoresis</fact15>, along with a sudden increase in <fact16>temperature to 39.1°C (102.4°F)</fact16> and <fact17>pulse to 130/min</fact17> after the <fact14>appendiceal base is ligated</fact14>, it is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia, a life-threatening condition that can be triggered by certain anesthetics and other stressors. The elevated <fact20>end-tidal CO2 of 85 mm Hg</fact20> further supports this diagnosis. Among the provided options, the most appropriate treatment for malignant hyperthermia is Dantrolene, which is a muscle relaxant that can help reduce the patient's metabolic rate and alleviate symptoms. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 47-year-old woman seeks evaluation at your office because she has had postcoital vaginal bleeding for the past 8 months with occasional intermenstrual watery, blood-tinged vaginal discharge. Her family history is negative for malignancies and inherited disorders. She is the result of a pregnancy complicated by numerous miscarriages in the 1960s, for which her mother received diethylstilbestrol. During a pelvic examination, you notice a polypoid mass on the anterior wall of the vagina. The bimanual examination is negative for adnexal masses. You suspect the presence of carcinoma and, therefore, send tissue samples to pathology, which confirmed the presence of malignant cells. Which of the following is the most likely malignant tumor in this patient?
A) Clear cell adenocarcinoma
B) Melanoma
C) Botryoid sarcoma
D) Verrucous carcinoma
E) Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>47-year-old woman</fact1> seeks evaluation at your office because she has had <fact2>postcoital vaginal bleeding</fact2> for the past <fact3>8 months</fact3> with occasional <fact4>intermenstrual watery, blood-tinged vaginal discharge</fact4>. Her family history is negative for malignancies and inherited disorders. She is the result of a pregnancy complicated by numerous miscarriages in the <fact5>1960s</fact5>, for which her mother received <fact6>diethylstilbestrol</fact6>. During a <fact7>pelvic examination</fact7>, you notice a <fact8>polypoid mass on the anterior wall of the vagina</fact8>. The <fact9>bimanual examination</fact9> is negative for adnexal masses. You suspect the presence of carcinoma and, therefore, send tissue samples to pathology, which confirmed the presence of malignant cells. Which of the following is the most likely malignant tumor in this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>postcoital vaginal bleeding</fact2> and <fact4>intermenstrual watery, blood-tinged vaginal discharge</fact4>, along with the finding of a <fact8>polypoid mass on the anterior wall of the vagina</fact8> during the <fact7>pelvic examination</fact7>, these are indicative of a vaginal tumor. The patient's exposure to <fact6>diethylstilbestrol</fact6> in utero, given to her mother during pregnancy in the <fact5>1960s</fact5>, significantly increases her risk for clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina. This type of cancer is a known complication of in utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol. Therefore, the most likely malignant tumor in this patient is clear cell adenocarcinoma, which is option {A}.

question:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of recurrent skin lesions. The episodes of lesions started at the age of 2 months and multiple treatment options have been attempted without success. He has also had several episodes of respiratory tract infections, enlarged lymph nodes, and recurrent fevers since birth. The boy attends daycare. His older brother has asthma. The patient's immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 5th percentile for length and 10th percentile for weight. He appears ill. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows several raised, erythematous lesions of different sizes over the face, neck, groins, and extremities; some secrete pus. Cervical and axillary lymph nodes are enlarged bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Chronic granulomatous disease
B) Ataxia-telangiectasia
C) Atopic dermatitis
D) Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome
E) Chediak-Higashi syndrome
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>3-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to the physician for the evaluation of <fact2>recurrent skin lesions</fact2>. The episodes of lesions started at the age of <fact3>2 months</fact3> and multiple treatment options have been attempted without success. He has also had several episodes of <fact4>respiratory tract infections</fact4>, <fact5>enlarged lymph nodes</fact5>, and <fact6>recurrent fevers</fact6> since birth. The boy attends daycare. His older brother has asthma. The patient's immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the <fact7>5th percentile for length and 10th percentile for weight</fact7>. He appears ill. His <fact8>temperature is 38°C (100.4°F)</fact8>, <fact9>pulse is 100/min</fact9>, and <fact10>blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg</fact10>. Examination shows several <fact11>raised, erythematous lesions of different sizes over the face, neck, groins, and extremities</fact11>; some secrete pus. <fact12>Cervical and axillary lymph nodes are enlarged bilaterally</fact12>. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>3-year-old boy's</fact1> history of <fact2>recurrent skin lesions</fact2> starting at <fact3>2 months</fact3> of age, along with <fact4>respiratory tract infections</fact4>, <fact5>enlarged lymph nodes</fact5>, and <fact6>recurrent fevers</fact6>, it suggests an underlying immunodeficiency condition. The presence of <fact11>raised, erythematous lesions of different sizes over the face, neck, groins, and extremities</fact11> that secrete pus, and <fact12>bilateral enlargement of cervical and axillary lymph nodes</fact12>, further supports this. Given these symptoms and the boy's failure to respond to multiple treatments, the most likely diagnosis is Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by eczema, thrombocytopenia, immune deficiency, and bloody diarrhea. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 78-year-old woman presents to the office for an annual health check-up with her family physician accompanied by her daughter. She has no complaints during this visit but her daughter states that she is having difficulty locating objects such as the television remote, car keys, and her purse. Her medical history is significant for Alzheimer’s dementia, coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, congestive heart failure, osteoarthritis and centrilobular emphysema. The patient takes memantine, atorvastatin, metformin, levothyroxine, lisinopril, aspirin, albuterol, and ipratropium. The patient’s vitals are within normal limits today. Physical exam reveals an elderly female in no acute distress, oriented to person, place and year, but not to month or day of the week. She has a 3/6 holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border along with an S3 gallop. There are mild crackles at the lung bases. The remainder of the exam is normal. A previous urine culture reports growth of > 100,000 CFU of Enterobacter. Urinalysis findings are offered below:
Leukocyte esterase  positive
WBCs 50-100 cell/HPF
Nitrites positive
RBCs 2 cell/HPF
Epithelial cells 2 cell/HPF
Urine pH 5.7
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
A) TMP-SMX
B) Nitrofurantoin
C) Levofloxacin
D) Cephalexin
E) No treatment is necessary
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>78-year-old woman</fact1> presents to the office for an annual health check-up with her family physician accompanied by her daughter. She has no complaints during this visit but her daughter states that she is having difficulty locating objects such as the television remote, car keys, and her purse. Her medical history is significant for <fact2>Alzheimer’s dementia, coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, congestive heart failure, osteoarthritis and centrilobular emphysema</fact2>. The patient takes <fact3>memantine, atorvastatin, metformin, levothyroxine, lisinopril, aspirin, albuterol, and ipratropium</fact3>. The patient’s vitals are within normal limits today. Physical exam reveals an elderly female in no acute distress, oriented to person, place and year, but not to month or day of the week. She has a <fact4>3/6 holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border along with an S3 gallop</fact4>. There are <fact5>mild crackles at the lung bases</fact5>. The remainder of the exam is normal. A previous <fact6>urine culture reports growth of > 100,000 CFU of Enterobacter</fact6>. <fact7>Urinalysis findings</fact7> are offered below:
<fact8>Leukocyte esterase  positive</fact8>
<fact9>WBCs 50-100 cell/HPF</fact9>
<fact10>Nitrites positive</fact10>
<fact11>RBCs 2 cell/HPF</fact11>
<fact12>Epithelial cells 2 cell/HPF</fact12>
<fact13>Urine pH 5.7</fact13>
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
A) TMP-SMX
B) Nitrofurantoin
C) Levofloxacin
D) Cephalexin
E) No treatment is necessary

Answer: 
Given the patient's <fact6>urine culture reports growth of > 100,000 CFU of Enterobacter</fact6> and the <fact7>urinalysis findings</fact7> indicating a urinary tract infection (evidenced by <fact8>leukocyte esterase positive</fact8>, <fact9>WBCs 50-100 cell/HPF</fact9>, and <fact10>nitrites positive</fact10>), treatment is necessary. However, considering the patient's medical history, particularly <fact2>Alzheimer’s dementia, coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, congestive heart failure, osteoarthritis and centrilobular emphysema</fact2>, and the medications she is taking (<fact3>memantine, atorvastatin, metformin, levothyroxine, lisinopril, aspirin, albuterol, and ipratropium</fact3>), the choice of antibiotic should be carefully selected to avoid interactions and exacerbation of her conditions. Among the options, Levofloxacin is a broad-spectrum antibiotic effective against Enterobacter and is less likely to interact with her current medications. Therefore, the most appropriate next step is option {C}.

question:
Three days after induction chemotherapy, a 9-year-old boy is admitted to the hospital for fever and neutropenia. He was initially diagnosed with t(9;22)-positive acute T cell lymphoblastic leukemia following workup for fatigue and pancytopenia. He is fully conscious. His blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg, temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), pulse is 98/min, and respiratory rate is 14/min. Physical examination including examination of the central venous catheter site shows no source of infection. Broad-spectrum antibiotics are initiated. Which of the following factors about this patient most strongly indicates a poor prognosis?
A) Age
B) Cytogenetics
C) Fever and neutropenia
D) Initial presentation
E) Immunological subtype
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
Three days after <fact1>induction chemotherapy</fact1>, a <fact2>9-year-old boy</fact2> is admitted to the hospital for <fact3>fever and neutropenia</fact3>. He was initially diagnosed with <fact4>t(9;22)-positive acute T cell lymphoblastic leukemia</fact4> following workup for <fact5>fatigue and pancytopenia</fact5>. He is fully conscious. His <fact6>blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg</fact6>, <fact7>temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F)</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 98/min</fact8>, and <fact9>respiratory rate is 14/min</fact9>. Physical examination including examination of the <fact10>central venous catheter site</fact10> shows no source of infection. <fact11>Broad-spectrum antibiotics</fact11> are initiated. Which of the following factors about this patient most strongly indicates a poor prognosis?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's diagnosis of <fact4>t(9;22)-positive acute T cell lymphoblastic leukemia</fact4>, this specific cytogenetic abnormality is associated with a poorer prognosis in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) patients. The t(9;22) translocation, also known as the Philadelphia chromosome, results in the creation of a BCR-ABL fusion gene, which is a potent oncogene that can drive the progression of leukemia. The presence of this translocation is generally associated with a more aggressive disease course and a higher risk of relapse. Therefore, the factor that most strongly indicates a poor prognosis for this patient is his cytogenetics, specifically the presence of the t(9;22) translocation. The answer is {B}.

question:
A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department. He was found unconscious on the street. The staff recognizes him as a local homeless man with a long history of alcoholism. At the hospital, his pulse is 95/min, the blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, the respirations are 20/min, and the oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam, the unconscious man is covered in bloody vomit with small clots and food particles. He smells of alcohol. A digital exam reveals black tarry stool in the rectal vault. The patient is given oxygen, IV fluids, and an NG-tube is placed and set to intermittent suction. Labs are sent and the patient is prepared for a procedure. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in his management?
A) Undergo colonoscopy
B) Undergo upper GI endoscopy
C) Selective mesenteric angiography
D) Proton pump inhibitors with anti-H.pylori regimen
E) Surgery for peptic ulcer disease
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>56-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department. He was found unconscious on the street. The staff recognizes him as a local homeless man with a <fact2>long history of alcoholism</fact2>. At the hospital, his <fact3>pulse is 95/min</fact3>, the <fact4>blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg</fact4>, the <fact5>respirations are 20/min</fact5>, and the <fact6>oxygen saturation is 98% on room air</fact6>. On physical exam, the unconscious man is covered in <fact7>bloody vomit with small clots and food particles</fact7>. He smells of alcohol. A digital exam reveals <fact8>black tarry stool in the rectal vault</fact8>. The patient is given oxygen, IV fluids, and an NG-tube is placed and set to intermittent suction. Labs are sent and the patient is prepared for a procedure. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in his management?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation with <fact7>bloody vomit with small clots and food particles</fact7> and <fact8>black tarry stool in the rectal vault</fact8>, these are indicative of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Given the patient's <fact2>long history of alcoholism</fact2>, this increases the risk for peptic ulcer disease, a common cause of upper GI bleeding. The immediate management involves stabilizing the patient, which has been done with oxygen, IV fluids, and NG-tube placement. The next step is to identify and potentially treat the source of bleeding. Among the options provided, the most appropriate next step is to undergo an upper GI endoscopy, which allows for both the identification of the bleeding source and potential therapeutic interventions to control the bleeding. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 9-year-old boy is brought in by his mother because of bruising on his torso and limbs. The patient’s mother denies any other symptoms and says he is otherwise healthy. Physical examination shows multiple petechiae and bruising on the torso and extremities bilaterally. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. A complete blood count is normal. His coagulation profile reveals:
Prothrombin time (PT) 12 sec
Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) 60 sec
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia
B) Hemophilia B
C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura
D) Von Willebrand disease
E) Hemophilia A
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>9-year-old boy</fact1> is brought in by his mother because of <fact2>bruising on his torso and limbs</fact2>. The patient’s mother denies any other symptoms and says he is otherwise healthy. Physical examination shows <fact3>multiple petechiae and bruising on the torso and extremities bilaterally</fact3>. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. A <fact4>complete blood count is normal</fact4>. His coagulation profile reveals: 
<fact5>Prothrombin time (PT) 12 sec</fact5> 
<fact6>Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) 60 sec</fact6> 
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient? 
A) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia 
B) Hemophilia B 
C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura 
D) Von Willebrand disease 
E) Hemophilia A 

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact2>bruising on his torso and limbs</fact2> and <fact3>multiple petechiae and bruising on the torso and extremities bilaterally</fact3>, along with a <fact4>normal complete blood count</fact4>, the most likely diagnosis is related to a coagulation disorder. The key to this question lies in the coagulation profile, which shows a <fact5>normal Prothrombin time (PT) of 12 sec</fact5> but an <fact6>elevated Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) of 60 sec</fact6>. This pattern is indicative of a problem in the intrinsic coagulation pathway. Hemophilia A, caused by a deficiency in factor VIII, is a condition that affects the intrinsic pathway and is characterized by an elevated aPTT with a normal PT. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis in this patient is {E}.

question:
A 7-month-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician by his mother. She reports that the child develops severe sunburns every time the infant is exposed to sunlight. She has applied copious amounts of sunscreen to the infant but this has not helped the problem. On examination, there are multiple areas of reddened skin primarily in sun exposed areas. The child’s corneas appear irritated and erythematous. Which of the following processes is likely impaired in this patient?
A) Nucleotide excision repair
B) Non-homologous end joining
C) Homologous recombination
D) Mismatch repair
E) Base excision repair
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>7-month-old male infant</fact1> is brought to the pediatrician by his mother. She reports that the child develops <fact2>severe sunburns</fact2> every time the <fact1>infant</fact1> is exposed to <fact3>sunlight</fact3>. She has applied copious amounts of <fact4>sunscreen</fact4> to the <fact1>infant</fact1> but this has not helped the problem. On examination, there are multiple areas of <fact5>reddened skin</fact5> primarily in <fact6>sun-exposed areas</fact6>. The child’s <fact7>corneas appear irritated and erythematous</fact7>. Which of the following processes is likely impaired in this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>7-month-old male infant</fact1> develops <fact2>severe sunburns</fact2> upon exposure to <fact3>sunlight</fact3>, despite the application of <fact4>sunscreen</fact4>, it suggests an inability to repair DNA damage caused by ultraviolet (UV) light. This condition is further supported by the presence of <fact5>reddened skin</fact5> in <fact6>sun-exposed areas</fact6> and <fact7>irritated and erythematous corneas</fact7>, indicating an increased sensitivity to UV radiation. The process likely impaired in this patient is nucleotide excision repair, which is responsible for repairing DNA damage caused by UV light. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
The only immunoglobulin found as a dimer has what primary function?
A) Protect against invasive helminth infection
B) Protect against viral infections
C) Provide an initial humoral immune response to newly presenting bacterial antigens
D) Inhibiting bacterial adherance and colonization of mucous membranes
E) Provides the most specific recognition to circulating antigens in the bloodstream
answer:
Reformatted Question: The only <fact1>immunoglobulin found as a dimer</fact1> has what primary function? 
A) Protect against invasive helminth infection
B) Protect against viral infections
C) Provide an initial humoral immune response to newly presenting bacterial antigens
D) Inhibiting bacterial adherence and colonization of mucous membranes
E) Provides the most specific recognition to circulating antigens in the bloodstream

Answer: The primary function of the <fact1>immunoglobulin found as a dimer</fact1> is to inhibit bacterial adherence and colonization of mucous membranes. This is characteristic of IgA, which is the only immunoglobulin that can exist as a dimer and plays a crucial role in mucosal immunity. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 40-year old man presents to the clinic with vague upper abdominal pain that has been worsening for the last several days. He says that he often gets similar pain but less severe and that it worsens with meals. The pain sometimes radiates to his back. He recently lost 15 kg (33.6 lb) of weight secondary to his lack of appetite since his last visit 2 months ago. He admits to drinking alcohol almost every night since the age of 17. His temperature is 37.0° C (98.6°F), respirations are 15/min, pulse is 67/min, and blood pressure is 122/98 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals moderate epigastric tenderness. An abdominal CT scan reveals calcifications as shown by the white arrows. Which of the following organs is affected in this patient?
A) Pancreas
B) Jejunum
C) Duodenum
D) Large intestine
E) Gall bladder
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>40-year-old man</fact1> presents to the clinic with <fact2>vague upper abdominal pain</fact2> that has been worsening for the last several days. He says that he often gets similar pain but less severe and that it <fact3>worsens with meals</fact3>. The pain sometimes <fact4>radiates to his back</fact4>. He recently lost <fact5>15 kg (33.6 lb) of weight</fact5> secondary to his lack of appetite since his last visit 2 months ago. He admits to <fact6>drinking alcohol almost every night since the age of 17</fact6>. His <fact7>temperature is 37.0° C (98.6°F)</fact7>, <fact8>respirations are 15/min</fact8>, <fact9>pulse is 67/min</fact9>, and <fact10>blood pressure is 122/98 mm Hg</fact10>. Physical examination reveals <fact11>moderate epigastric tenderness</fact11>. An <fact12>abdominal CT scan reveals calcifications as shown by the white arrows</fact12>. Which of the following organs is affected in this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>vague upper abdominal pain</fact2> that <fact3>worsens with meals</fact3> and sometimes <fact4>radiates to his back</fact4>, along with the physical examination finding of <fact11>moderate epigastric tenderness</fact11>, these are indicative of pancreatic pathology. Additionally, the patient's history of <fact6>drinking alcohol almost every night since the age of 17</fact6> increases his risk for pancreatitis, a condition that can lead to calcifications visible on imaging. The <fact12>abdominal CT scan revealing calcifications</fact12> further supports this diagnosis. Given these factors, the organ most likely affected in this patient is the pancreas. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 3-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 4-hour history of somnolence, poor feeding, and one episode of vomiting. He is exclusively breastfed. His serum glucose concentration is 88 mg/dL and his serum ammonia concentration is 850 μmol/L (N<90). Urinalysis shows an increased orotic acid to creatinine ratio. Urinary ketones are absent. This patient is most likely deficient in an enzyme that catalyzes which of the following reactions?
A) Ornithine and carbamoyl phosphate to citrulline
B) Orotic acid to uridine monophosphate
C) Pyruvate to acetyl-coenzyme A
D) Glutamate and acetyl-coenzyme A to N-acetylglutamate
E) Arginine to urea and ornithine
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>3-day-old boy</fact1> is brought to the emergency department because of a <fact2>4-hour history of somnolence, poor feeding, and one episode of vomiting</fact2>. He is <fact3>exclusively breastfed</fact3>. His <fact4>serum glucose concentration is 88 mg/dL</fact4> and his <fact5>serum ammonia concentration is 850 μmol/L (N<90)</fact5>. <fact6>Urinalysis shows an increased orotic acid to creatinine ratio</fact6>. <fact7>Urinary ketones are absent</fact7>. This patient is most likely deficient in an enzyme that catalyzes which of the following reactions?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms, including <fact2>somnolence, poor feeding, and vomiting</fact2>, along with the laboratory findings of <fact5>elevated serum ammonia concentration</fact5> and <fact6>increased orotic acid to creatinine ratio in urinalysis</fact6>, it suggests a disorder of the urea cycle. The absence of <fact7>urinary ketones</fact7> and a relatively normal <fact4>serum glucose concentration</fact4> further supports this diagnosis. Among the options provided, the enzyme catalyzing the reaction of ornithine and carbamoyl phosphate to citrulline is directly involved in the urea cycle, and its deficiency (Ornithine Transcarbamylase deficiency) is consistent with the patient's presentation, including the elevated orotic acid levels due to carbamoyl phosphate accumulation and its subsequent shunting into the pyrimidine synthesis pathway. Therefore, the correct answer is {A}.

question:
A 27-year-old gentleman is brought into the ED after being stabbed in the back by a knife. In addition to the pain from the wound, he complains of weakness in his left leg. Upon physical examination you find that he has no other visible injuries; however, he has 2/5 strength in the left lower extremity. Complete neurologic exam also finds a deficit in vibration sense and light touch on the left lower extremity as well as a loss of pain and temperature sensation in the right lower extremity. Which of the following lesions would result in the syndrome described?
A) Anterior cord lesion
B) Posterior cord lesion
C) Right cord hemisection
D) Left cord hemisection
E) Complete cord transection
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>27-year-old gentleman</fact1> is brought into the ED after being stabbed in the back by a knife. In addition to the pain from the wound, he complains of <fact2>weakness in his left leg</fact2>. Upon physical examination you find that he has no other visible injuries; however, he has <fact3>2/5 strength in the left lower extremity</fact3>. Complete neurologic exam also finds a deficit in <fact4>vibration sense and light touch on the left lower extremity</fact4> as well as a loss of <fact5>pain and temperature sensation in the right lower extremity</fact5>. Which of the following lesions would result in the syndrome described?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms, the <fact2>weakness in his left leg</fact2> and <fact3>2/5 strength in the left lower extremity</fact3> indicate a motor deficit on the left side. The deficit in <fact4>vibration sense and light touch on the left lower extremity</fact4> suggests a lesion affecting the posterior columns of the spinal cord on the left side, which are responsible for transmitting these sensations. However, the loss of <fact5>pain and temperature sensation in the right lower extremity</fact5> indicates a lesion affecting the spinothalamic tract on the left side of the spinal cord, which transmits pain and temperature sensations from the opposite side of the body. These findings are consistent with a lesion that affects both the posterior columns and the spinothalamic tract on one side of the spinal cord, which is characteristic of a hemisection of the spinal cord. Given that the motor and posterior column deficits are on the left side, and the spinothalamic tract deficit is on the right side, the lesion must be on the left side of the spinal cord. Therefore, the correct answer is {D}.

question:
A 29-year-old woman presents to the physician with a blurred vision of her right eye for 2 days. She has pain around her right eye during eye movement. She takes no medications. At the clinic, her blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, the pulse is 72/min, respirations are 15/min, and the temperature is 36.5℃ (97.7℉). On physical examination, illumination of the left eye results in bilateral pupillary constriction while illumination of the right eye results in a mild bilateral pupillary dilation. Fundoscopic examination shows optic disk swelling in the right eye. The color vision test shows decreased perception in the right eye. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Specific additional history should be obtained regarding which of the following?
A) Dry eyes
B) High-risk sexual behaviour
C) Oral ulcers
D) Sensory loss
E) Late preterm birth
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>29-year-old woman</fact1> presents to the physician with a <fact2>blurred vision of her right eye for 2 days</fact2>. She has <fact3>pain around her right eye during eye movement</fact3>. She takes no medications. At the clinic, her <fact4>blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg</fact4>, the <fact5>pulse is 72/min</fact5>, <fact6>respirations are 15/min</fact6>, and the <fact7>temperature is 36.5℃ (97.7℉)</fact7>. On physical examination, <fact8>illumination of the left eye results in bilateral pupillary constriction while illumination of the right eye results in a mild bilateral pupillary dilation</fact8>. <fact9>Fundoscopic examination shows optic disk swelling in the right eye</fact9>. The <fact10>color vision test shows decreased perception in the right eye</fact10>. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Specific additional history should be obtained regarding which of the following?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms, particularly the <fact2>blurred vision of her right eye for 2 days</fact2> accompanied by <fact3>pain around her right eye during eye movement</fact3>, along with the findings of <fact9>optic disk swelling in the right eye</fact9> and <fact10>decreased color perception in the right eye</fact10>, the clinical presentation is suggestive of optic neuritis. This condition is often associated with multiple sclerosis, a demyelinating disease of the central nervous system. Given the potential link between optic neuritis and multiple sclerosis, it would be pertinent to inquire about other symptoms that might indicate central nervous system involvement. Among the options provided, option D, sensory loss, is a common symptom in multiple sclerosis and would be relevant to investigate further. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
An otherwise healthy 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of increasingly frequent episodes of upper abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. He has had a 3.2-kg (7-lb) weight loss during this time. Physical examination shows bilateral pitting pedal edema. An endoscopy shows prominent rugae in the gastric fundus. Biopsy shows parietal cell atrophy. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause?
A) Serotonin-secreting gastric tumor
B) Proliferation of gastric mucus-producing cells
C) Neoplasia of submucosal lymphoid tissue
D) Excessive somatostatin secretion
E) Ectopic secretion of gastrin
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
An otherwise healthy <fact1>50-year-old man</fact1> comes to the physician because of a <fact2>6-month history of increasingly frequent episodes of upper abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea</fact2>. He has had a <fact3>3.2-kg (7-lb) weight loss</fact3> during this time. Physical examination shows <fact4>bilateral pitting pedal edema</fact4>. An <fact5>endoscopy shows prominent rugae in the gastric fundus</fact5>. <fact6>Biopsy shows parietal cell atrophy</fact6>. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>upper abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea</fact2> along with <fact3>weight loss</fact3> and <fact4>bilateral pitting pedal edema</fact4>, these are indicative of malabsorption. The findings of <fact5>prominent rugae in the gastric fundus</fact5> on endoscopy and <fact6>parietal cell atrophy</fact6> on biopsy point towards atrophic gastritis. Among the options provided, the most likely underlying cause is related to an autoimmune process or nutritional deficiency that leads to atrophic gastritis. However, given the choices, option B, which refers to the proliferation of gastric mucus-producing cells, is not directly related to the described pathology but is the closest in the context of gastric abnormalities. Yet, it's essential to note that this option doesn't perfectly match the expected cause of atrophic gastritis, which often involves autoimmune destruction of parietal cells or nutritional deficiencies, not directly listed among the options.

question:
A previously healthy 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation because of loss of appetite, sleeplessness, and extreme irritability for the past 3 weeks. He was recently kicked off of the school's football team after missing too many practices. He has also been avoiding his family and friends because he is not in the mood to see them, but he admits that he is lonely. He has not left his room for 2 days, which prompted his father to bring him to the physician. He has no medical conditions and does not take any medications. He does not drink alcohol or use recreational drugs. While the father is in the waiting room, a mental status examination is conducted, which shows a constricted affect. Cognition is intact. He says that he would be better off dead and refuses to be treated. He says he wants to use his father's licensed firearm to “end his misery” over the weekend when his parents are at church. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Agree to his wish for no further treatment
B) Begin paroxetine therapy
C) Involuntary hospitalization after informing the parents
D) Reassure the patient that he will feel better
E) Start outpatient psychotherapy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A previously healthy <fact1>14-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to the physician for evaluation because of <fact2>loss of appetite, sleeplessness, and extreme irritability</fact2> for the past <fact3>3 weeks</fact3>. He was recently kicked off of the school's football team after missing too many practices. He has also been avoiding his family and friends because he is not in the mood to see them, but he admits that he is <fact4>lonely</fact4>. He has not left his room for <fact5>2 days</fact5>, which prompted his father to bring him to the physician. He has no medical conditions and does not take any medications. He does not drink alcohol or use recreational drugs. While the father is in the waiting room, a mental status examination is conducted, which shows a <fact6>constricted affect</fact6>. Cognition is intact. He says that he would be <fact7>better off dead</fact7> and refuses to be treated. He says he wants to use his father's licensed firearm to “<fact8>end his misery</fact8>” over the weekend when his parents are at church. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: 
Given the <fact1>14-year-old boy's</fact1> symptoms of <fact2>loss of appetite, sleeplessness, and extreme irritability</fact2> over the past <fact3>3 weeks</fact3>, along with feelings of being <fact4>lonely</fact4> and having a <fact6>constricted affect</fact6>, it is clear that he is experiencing significant emotional distress. His statements about being <fact7>better off dead</fact7> and wanting to “<fact8>end his misery</fact8>” using his father's firearm indicate a high risk of suicide. This is a medical emergency that requires immediate intervention to ensure the patient's safety. Among the provided options, the most appropriate next step in management is to ensure the patient's safety through constant supervision and by removing access to means of self-harm. Therefore, involuntary hospitalization after informing the parents is the most appropriate course of action. The answer is {C}.

question:
A 48-year-old Caucasian female presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of progressive weakness and shortness of breath. She has had progressive shortness of breath over the last year with an intermittent non-productive cough. In addition, she complains of difficulty raising her arms to brush her hair. Her temperature is 99.6°F (37.6°C), pulse is 80/min, blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Neurologic exam shows 4/5 strength in the deltoid muscles bilaterally. Diffuse dry crackles are heard on lung auscultation. A faint erythematous rash is noted on the malar cheeks, periorbital areas, lateral proximal thighs, and the elbows. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
A) Muscle biopsy
B) CT scan
C) Pulmonary function tests
D) Serum ANA titer
E) Skin biopsy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>48-year-old Caucasian female</fact1> presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of <fact2>progressive weakness and shortness of breath</fact2>. She has had <fact3>progressive shortness of breath over the last year</fact3> with an intermittent non-productive cough. In addition, she complains of <fact4>difficulty raising her arms to brush her hair</fact4>. Her <fact5>temperature is 99.6°F (37.6°C)</fact5>, <fact6>pulse is 80/min</fact6>, <fact7>blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg</fact7>, <fact8>respirations are 18/min</fact8>, and <fact9>oxygen saturation is 95% on room air</fact9>. Neurologic exam shows <fact10>4/5 strength in the deltoid muscles bilaterally</fact10>. <fact11>Diffuse dry crackles are heard on lung auscultation</fact11>. A <fact12>faint erythematous rash is noted on the malar cheeks, periorbital areas, lateral proximal thighs, and the elbows</fact12>. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>progressive weakness and shortness of breath</fact2>, along with the specific findings of <fact10>4/5 strength in the deltoid muscles bilaterally</fact10> and <fact11>diffuse dry crackles on lung auscultation</fact11>, these are indicative of a systemic condition affecting both the musculoskeletal and respiratory systems. Additionally, the presence of a <fact12>faint erythematous rash on the malar cheeks, periorbital areas, lateral proximal thighs, and the elbows</fact12> is highly suggestive of dermatomyositis, a condition often associated with autoimmune diseases. Given these observations, the most likely test to confirm the diagnosis would be a muscle biopsy, which can provide definitive evidence of muscle inflammation and damage characteristic of dermatomyositis. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 63-year-old man is aiming to improve his health by eating a well balanced diet, walking daily, and quitting smoking following a 45-year smoking history. While on his daily walks he notices a strong cramping pain in his calves that consistently appears after a mile of walking.
