He sees his physician and a diagnosis of peripheral artery disease with intermittent claudication is made. To improve his symptoms, cilostazol is prescribed. What is the mechanism of action of this medication?
A) Irreversible cyclooxygenase inhibitor
B) Glycoprotein IIB/IIIA inhibitor
C) Thromboxane synthase inhibitor
D) Adenosine diphosphate receptor inhibitor
E) Phosphodiesterase inhibitor
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>63-year-old man</fact1> is aiming to improve his health by eating a well-balanced diet, walking daily, and quitting smoking following a <fact2>45-year smoking history</fact2>. While on his daily walks, he notices a strong <fact3>cramping pain in his calves</fact3> that consistently appears after a mile of walking. He sees his physician and a diagnosis of <fact4>peripheral artery disease with intermittent claudication</fact4> is made. To improve his symptoms, <fact5>cilostazol</fact5> is prescribed. What is the mechanism of action of this medication?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's diagnosis of <fact4>peripheral artery disease with intermittent claudication</fact4>, <fact5>cilostazol</fact5> is prescribed to alleviate symptoms. Cilostazol works by inhibiting phosphodiesterase, an enzyme that breaks down cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) in the blood vessels. By preventing the breakdown of cAMP, cilostazol leads to vasodilation and improved blood flow to the affected areas, thereby reducing the <fact3>cramping pain in the calves</fact3> associated with intermittent claudication. Therefore, the mechanism of action of cilostazol is as a phosphodiesterase inhibitor. The answer is {E}.

question:
A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fever, generalized fatigue, and chills for 1 week. She has been having dull right-side abdominal pain during this period. She has nausea. She has no history of travel outside the United States. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include insulin and an oral contraceptive. She appears ill. Her temperature is 40°C (104°F), pulse is 118/min, and blood pressure is 106/70 mm Hg. On examination, the liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin and is tender. There are decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 14.1 g/dL
Leukocyte count 17,100/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 74%
Eosinophils 1%
Lymphocytes 20%
Monocytes 5%
Serum
Glucose 79 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL
Total bilirubin 0.9 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 180 U/L
AST 69 U/L
ALT 100 U/L
A right upper quadrant ultrasound is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?"
A) Discontinue the oral contraceptive
B) Obtain hepatoiminodiacetic acid scan
C) Perform endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
D) Administer metronidazole
E) Perform percutaneous drainage
"
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>39-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>fever, generalized fatigue, and chills for 1 week</fact2>. She has been having <fact3>dull right-side abdominal pain</fact3> during this period. She has <fact4>nausea</fact4>. She has no history of travel outside the United States. She has <fact5>type 1 diabetes mellitus</fact5>. Current medications include <fact6>insulin and an oral contraceptive</fact6>. She appears ill. Her <fact7>temperature is 40°C (104°F)</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 118/min</fact8>, and <fact9>blood pressure is 106/70 mm Hg</fact9>. On examination, the <fact10>liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin and is tender</fact10>. There are <fact11>decreased breath sounds over the right lung base</fact11>. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: <fact12>Leukocyte count 17,100/mm3</fact12>, <fact13>Segmented neutrophils 74%</fact13>, <fact14>Serum alkaline phosphatase 180 U/L</fact14>, <fact15>Serum AST 69 U/L</fact15>, and <fact16>Serum ALT 100 U/L</fact16>. A <fact17>right upper quadrant ultrasound</fact17> is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer:
Given the patient's presentation of <fact2>fever, generalized fatigue, and chills for 1 week</fact2>, along with <fact3>dull right-side abdominal pain</fact3> and <fact4>nausea</fact4>, combined with the laboratory findings of elevated <fact12>leukocyte count</fact12> and liver enzymes (<fact14>alkaline phosphatase</fact14>, <fact15>AST</fact15>, and <fact16>ALT</fact16>), there is a strong indication of a liver or biliary tract infection. The <fact10>tender liver palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin</fact10> and the <fact11>decreased breath sounds over the right lung base</fact11> further support this diagnosis, possibly suggesting an abscess or infection in the liver. The most appropriate next step in management would be to perform a procedure that can help in diagnosing and potentially treating the infection or abscess. Among the options provided, performing <fact18>percutaneous drainage</fact18> (option E) would be the most appropriate next step as it allows for both the diagnosis (obtaining a sample for culture) and treatment (drainage of the abscess) of a potential liver abscess, which is likely given the patient's symptoms and laboratory findings.

question:
A 16-year-old patient presents to the physician’s office with an absence of menstruations. Her last period was 6 months ago. Since almost a year and a half ago, she intentionally restricted her diet at the expense of carbohydrates, exercised intensively, and lost 18.0 kg (39.7 lb). She had her menarche at the age of 12 and menstruated normally until last year. She is not sexually active. On physical examination, the vital signs include blood pressure 100/60 mm Hg, heart rate 55/min, respiratory rate 12/min, and temperature 35.9°C (96.6°F). Her weight is 55.0 kg (121.3 lb), and her height is 166 cm (5 ft 5 in). Physical examination reveals the good development of muscles and decreased adiposity. A bone scan shows decreased calcium mineral deposits. Which statement about this patient’s condition is correct?
A) Hypertrophied muscles are the source of additional androgens which interfere with the patient’s menstrual cycle
B) This patient has insulin resistance
C) Decreased adiposity contributes to hypoestrogenemia in this patient
D) The patient is likely to have decreased blood estrogen concentration due to increased liver metabolism
E) The patient should be checked for hyperthyroidism because such extensive lipolysis is likely to result from thyroid hyperfunction
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>16-year-old patient</fact1> presents to the physician’s office with an <fact2>absence of menstruations</fact2>. Her last period was <fact3>6 months ago</fact3>. Since almost a year and a half ago, she <fact4>intentionally restricted her diet at the expense of carbohydrates, exercised intensively, and lost 18.0 kg (39.7 lb)</fact4>. She had her <fact5>menarche at the age of 12</fact5> and menstruated normally until last year. She is not sexually active. On physical examination, the vital signs include <fact6>blood pressure 100/60 mm Hg, heart rate 55/min, respiratory rate 12/min, and temperature 35.9°C (96.6°F)</fact6>. Her <fact7>weight is 55.0 kg (121.3 lb)</fact7>, and her <fact8>height is 166 cm (5 ft 5 in)</fact8>. Physical examination reveals the <fact9>good development of muscles and decreased adiposity</fact9>. A <fact10>bone scan shows decreased calcium mineral deposits</fact10>. Which statement about this patient’s condition is correct?

A) Hypertrophied muscles are the source of additional androgens which interfere with the patient’s menstrual cycle
B) This patient has insulin resistance
C) Decreased adiposity contributes to hypoestrogenemia in this patient
D) The patient is likely to have decreased blood estrogen concentration due to increased liver metabolism
E) The patient should be checked for hyperthyroidism because such extensive lipolysis is likely to result from thyroid hyperfunction

Answer: 
Analyzing the situation, the <fact1>16-year-old patient</fact1> presents with an <fact2>absence of menstruations</fact2> for <fact3>6 months</fact3>, which started after she <fact4>restricted her diet, exercised intensively, and lost a significant amount of weight</fact4>. Her physical examination reveals <fact9>good development of muscles and decreased adiposity</fact9>, and a <fact10>bone scan shows decreased calcium mineral deposits</fact10>. The most plausible explanation for her condition is related to her decreased body fat. Adipose tissue plays a crucial role in the production of estrogen through the aromatization of androgens. With decreased adiposity, there is less tissue available for this conversion, leading to lower estrogen levels. Therefore, option C, which states that decreased adiposity contributes to hypoestrogenemia in this patient, is the correct answer.

question:
An 18-year-old male presents to the emergency department trauma bay with a gunshot wound to the abdomen. The patient undergoes an exploratory laparotomy, during which, it is discovered that his splenic artery was damaged at its origin from the celiac trunk. The surgeon ligates the splenic artery at its origin. Which of the following arteries will now be hypoperfused as a result?
A) Left gastric artery
B) Gastroduodenal artery
C) Right gastroepiploic artery
D) Left gastroepiploic artery
E) Common hepatic artery
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
An <fact1>18-year-old male</fact1> presents to the emergency department trauma bay with a <fact2>gunshot wound to the abdomen</fact2>. The patient undergoes an <fact3>exploratory laparotomy</fact3>, during which, it is discovered that his <fact4>splenic artery was damaged at its origin from the celiac trunk</fact4>. The surgeon <fact5>ligates the splenic artery at its origin</fact5>. Which of the following arteries will now be <fact6>hypoperfused as a result</fact6>?

A) Left gastric artery
B) Gastroduodenal artery
C) Right gastroepiploic artery
D) Left gastroepiploic artery
E) Common hepatic artery

Answer: 
Given that the <fact4>splenic artery was damaged at its origin from the celiac trunk</fact4> and the surgeon had to <fact5>ligate the splenic artery at its origin</fact5>, this would directly impact the blood flow to the spleen and its subsequent branches. The <fact6>hypoperfused</fact6> area would be related to the branches of the splenic artery. Among the options provided, the left gastroepiploic artery is a direct branch of the splenic artery. Therefore, the artery that will now be <fact6>hypoperfused as a result</fact6> of the ligation is the left gastroepiploic artery. The answer is {D}.

question:
A 72-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for treatment of unstable angina. Cardiac catheterization shows occlusion that has caused a 50% reduction in the diameter of the left circumflex artery. Resistance to blood flow in this vessel has increased by what factor relative to a vessel with no occlusion?
A) 64
B) 16
C) 8
D) 4
E) 32
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>72-year-old woman</fact1> is admitted to the hospital for treatment of <fact2>unstable angina</fact2>. Cardiac catheterization shows <fact3>occlusion that has caused a 50% reduction in the diameter</fact3> of the <fact4>left circumflex artery</fact4>. Resistance to blood flow in this vessel has increased by what factor relative to a vessel with no occlusion?

Answer: 
To solve this problem, we need to understand the relationship between the diameter of a vessel and resistance to blood flow. According to Poiseuille's law, resistance to fluid flow is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the radius of the vessel. Since the diameter is reduced by 50% (<fact3>occlusion that has caused a 50% reduction in the diameter</fact3>), the radius is also reduced by 50%. 

We can calculate the factor by which resistance has increased as follows: 

New radius = 0.5 * old radius (since diameter is reduced by 50%, radius is also reduced by 50%)
New resistance = old resistance / (0.5)^4 = 16 * old resistance

Therefore, the resistance to blood flow in the <fact4>left circumflex artery</fact4> has increased by a factor of 16 relative to a vessel with no occlusion. The answer is {B}.

question:
A 69-year-old male with a longstanding history of hypertension and high cholesterol presents with abdominal pain and ‘bruising on his feet’. The patient states that his symptoms started about a week ago and have steadily worsened. He describes the abdominal pain as mild to moderate, dull, and deeply localized to the umbilical region. Past medical history is significant for 2 transient ischemic attacks 6 months prior, characterized by a sudden right-sided weakness and trouble speaking but recovered fully within 30 minutes. Current medications are sildenafil 100 mg orally as needed. Patient reports a 30-pack-year smoking history and heavy alcohol use on the weekends. Review of systems is significant for decreased appetite and feeling easily full. Vitals are temperature 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure 155/89 mm Hg, pulse 89/min, respirations 16/min, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is alert and cooperative. The cardiac exam is normal. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Carotid bruit present on the right. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Bowel sounds present. A pulsatile abdominal mass is felt in the lower umbilical region. Patient’s feet have the following appearance seen in the picture. Abdominal ultrasound reveals the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Contrast CT reveals a small, unruptured AAA (diameter 4.1 cm). High flow supplemental oxygen and fluid resuscitation are initiated. Morphine sulfate and metoprolol are administered. Which of the following is the best course of treatment for this patient?
 
A) Discharge with clinical surveillance and annual ultrasound
B) Discharge with clinical surveillance and ultrasound every 6 months
C) Elective endovascular repair
D) Elective open surgical repair
E) Emergency open surgical repair
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>69-year-old male</fact1> with a longstanding history of <fact2>hypertension and high cholesterol</fact2> presents with <fact3>abdominal pain</fact3> and ‘<fact4>bruising on his feet</fact4>’. The patient states that his symptoms started about a week ago and have steadily worsened. He describes the <fact3>abdominal pain</fact3> as mild to moderate, dull, and deeply localized to the <fact5>umbilical region</fact5>. Past medical history is significant for <fact6>2 transient ischemic attacks 6 months prior</fact6>, characterized by a sudden right-sided weakness and trouble speaking but recovered fully within 30 minutes. Current medications are sildenafil 100 mg orally as needed. Patient reports a <fact7>30-pack-year smoking history</fact7> and heavy alcohol use on the weekends. Review of systems is significant for decreased appetite and feeling easily full. Vitals are temperature 37°C (98.6°F), <fact8>blood pressure 155/89 mm Hg</fact8>, pulse 89/min, respirations 16/min, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is alert and cooperative. The cardiac exam is normal. Lungs are clear to auscultation. <fact9>Carotid bruit present on the right</fact9>. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Bowel sounds present. A <fact10>pulsatile abdominal mass</fact10> is felt in the lower <fact5>umbilical region</fact5>. Patient’s feet have the following appearance seen in the picture. <fact11>Abdominal ultrasound reveals the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)</fact11>. <fact12>Contrast CT reveals a small, unruptured AAA (diameter 4.1 cm)</fact12>. High flow supplemental oxygen and fluid resuscitation are initiated. Morphine sulfate and metoprolol are administered. Which of the following is the best course of treatment for this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact1>age of 69 years</fact1> and history of <fact2>hypertension and high cholesterol</fact2>, along with the presence of a <fact10>pulsatile abdominal mass</fact10> and <fact11>abdominal ultrasound revealing an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)</fact11>, the best course of treatment needs to balance the risks of rupture with the risks of surgical intervention. The <fact12>contrast CT showing a small, unruptured AAA with a diameter of 4.1 cm</fact12> is crucial for determining the best approach. Given the size of the aneurysm is greater than 4 cm but less than 5.5 cm, the patient is in a grey area where the decision to operate or monitor closely is nuanced. However, considering the patient's history of <fact6>transient ischemic attacks</fact6> and <fact7>30-pack-year smoking history</fact7>, which increase his risk for complications, a more conservative approach with close surveillance may be appropriate. The Society for Vascular Surgery recommends surveillance for AAAs between 4 and 5.4 cm in diameter. Therefore, the best course of treatment for this patient is to discharge with clinical surveillance and ultrasound every 6 months to monitor the size of the aneurysm and intervene if it grows significantly. The answer is {B}.

question:
Six days after undergoing surgical repair of a hip fracture, a previously healthy 79-year-old woman is agitated and confused. She is unarousable during the day, but then is awake and impulsive during the night, requiring frequent reorientation. Her husband says that she usually drinks one to two glasses of wine weekly. Her only current medication is oxycodone for pain. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She is distressed and oriented to person but not to place or time. Neurologic examination shows inattentiveness but no focal deficits. Urine dipstick is normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her current condition?
A) Dementia
B) Alcohol withdrawal
C) Opioid intoxication
D) Delirium
E) Urinary tract infection
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
Six days after undergoing surgical repair of a <fact1>hip fracture</fact1>, a previously healthy <fact2>79-year-old woman</fact2> is <fact3>agitated and confused</fact3>. She is <fact4>unarousable during the day, but then is awake and impulsive during the night</fact4>, requiring frequent reorientation. Her husband says that she usually drinks <fact5>one to two glasses of wine weekly</fact5>. Her only current medication is <fact6>oxycodone for pain</fact6>. Her <fact7>vital signs are within normal limits</fact7>. She is <fact8>distressed and oriented to person but not to place or time</fact8>. Neurologic examination shows <fact9>inattentiveness but no focal deficits</fact9>. <fact10>Urine dipstick is normal</fact10>. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her current condition?

Answer: 
Analyzing the situation, the <fact2>79-year-old woman</fact2> is experiencing <fact3>agitation and confusion</fact3> six days after surgery for a <fact1>hip fracture</fact1>. Her pattern of being <fact4>unarousable during the day but awake and impulsive at night</fact4> is indicative of a disrupted sleep-wake cycle. Given her age and recent surgery, she is at high risk for delirium, which is characterized by an acute onset of fluctuating cognitive impairment, including <fact8>distress and disorientation</fact8> as well as <fact9>inattentiveness without focal neurologic deficits</fact9>. The fact that her <fact7>vital signs are within normal limits</fact7> and <fact10>urine dipstick is normal</fact10> helps rule out other acute medical causes. Her minimal alcohol use of <fact5>one to two glasses of wine weekly</fact5> makes alcohol withdrawal unlikely, and while <fact6>oxycodone for pain</fact6> could contribute to confusion, the overall clinical picture is more suggestive of delirium. Therefore, the most likely cause of her current condition is {D}.

question:
A 27-year-old woman with no past medical history presents to the emergency department with recurrent wrist and neck pain for the last 2 months. She reports that her fingers feel stiff in the morning and the symptoms tend to improve as the day progresses. She denies any recent trauma or other inciting events. Family history is significant for a grandmother who suffered from fibromyalgia. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 16/min, and heart rate is 70/min. On physical examination, her metacarpophalangeal joints are erythematous and tender. Which of the following would be most helpful for diagnosing this patient’s condition?
A) Synovial fluid analysis
B) Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibody
C) Rheumatoid factor
D) CT scan
E) X-ray of cervical spine
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>27-year-old woman</fact1> with no past medical history presents to the emergency department with <fact2>recurrent wrist and neck pain</fact2> for the last <fact3>2 months</fact3>. She reports that her <fact4>fingers feel stiff in the morning</fact4> and the symptoms tend to <fact5>improve as the day progresses</fact5>. She denies any recent trauma or other inciting events. Family history is significant for a grandmother who suffered from <fact6>fibromyalgia</fact6>. Her <fact7>temperature is 37°C (98.6°F)</fact7>, <fact8>blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg</fact8>, <fact9>respiratory rate is 16/min</fact9>, and <fact10>heart rate is 70/min</fact10>. On physical examination, her <fact11>metacarpophalangeal joints are erythematous and tender</fact11>. Which of the following would be most helpful for diagnosing this patient’s condition?

A) Synovial fluid analysis
B) Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibody
C) Rheumatoid factor
D) CT scan
E) X-ray of cervical spine

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>recurrent wrist and neck pain</fact2> and <fact4>stiff fingers in the morning</fact4> that <fact5>improve as the day progresses</fact5>, along with the physical examination findings of <fact11>erythematous and tender metacarpophalangeal joints</fact11>, the clinical picture is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The presence of <fact6>fibromyalgia</fact6> in the family history is noted but does not directly influence the choice of diagnostic test for the patient's current symptoms. Among the options provided, the anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibody is a specific marker for rheumatoid arthritis and can be particularly useful in distinguishing RA from other causes of arthritis. Therefore, the most helpful test for diagnosing this patient's condition would be option {B}.

question:
A 25-year-old female with Hodgkin's lymphoma presents with a several day history of edema. Lab studies show:

Serum Na+: 140 mmol/L
Serum K+: 3.5 mmol/L
Serum albumin: 1.9 g/dL
Total serum bilirubin: 1.0 mg/dL
Serum creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL

Urinalysis shows 4+ proteinuria and fatty casts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis
B) Membranous nephropathy
C) Minimal change disease
D) Amyloidosis
E) Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>25-year-old female with Hodgkin's lymphoma</fact1> presents with a several day history of <fact2>edema</fact2>. Lab studies show:

<fact3>Serum Na+: 140 mmol/L</fact3>
<fact4>Serum K+: 3.5 mmol/L</fact4>
<fact5>Serum albumin: 1.9 g/dL</fact5>
<fact6>Total serum bilirubin: 1.0 mg/dL</fact6>
<fact7>Serum creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL</fact7>

Urinalysis shows <fact8>4+ proteinuria</fact8> and <fact9>fatty casts</fact9>. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact1>history of Hodgkin's lymphoma</fact1> and the presentation of <fact2>edema</fact2>, along with the laboratory findings of <fact5>low serum albumin</fact5> and <fact8>4+ proteinuria</fact8> with <fact9>fatty casts</fact9> in the urinalysis, the most likely diagnosis is Minimal Change Disease (MCD). MCD is often associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma and is characterized by significant proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia, which are evident in this patient's lab results. The presence of fatty casts in the urine further supports this diagnosis, as they are indicative of significant protein loss through the kidneys. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 30-year-old Japanese woman is brought to the emergency department after fainting at work. She says she was only unconscious for a moment and recovered quickly. She reports increasing fatigue and joint pain for the past 4 months. Her blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, and her temperature is 36.6°C (98.0°F). On physical examination, the patient is fully conscious. Her radial pulse is absent at her right wrist and 1+ at her left wrist. Laboratory findings are significant for the following:
Hemoglobin: 10.9 g/dL
Hematocrit: 34.7%
Leukocyte count: 5,500/mm3
Neutrophils: 65%
Lymphocytes: 30%
Monocytes: 5%
Mean corpuscular volume: 78.2 μm3
Platelet count: 190,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: 56 mm/h
What complications is this patient at risk for?
A) Amaurosis fugax
B) Myocardial infarction
C) Tongue infarction
D) Palpable purpura
E) Polyneuropathy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>30-year-old Japanese woman</fact1> is brought to the emergency department after <fact2>fainting at work</fact2>. She says she was only unconscious for a moment and recovered quickly. She reports increasing <fact3>fatigue and joint pain</fact3> for the past <fact4>4 months</fact4>. Her <fact5>blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg</fact5>, and her <fact6>temperature is 36.6°C (98.0°F)</fact6>. On physical examination, the patient is fully conscious. Her <fact7>radial pulse is absent at her right wrist and 1+ at her left wrist</fact7>. Laboratory findings are significant for the following:
<fact8>Hemoglobin: 10.9 g/dL</fact8>
<fact9>Hematocrit: 34.7%</fact9>
<fact10>Leukocyte count: 5,500/mm3</fact10>
<fact11>Neutrophils: 65%</fact11>
<fact12>Lymphocytes: 30%</fact12>
<fact13>Monocytes: 5%</fact13>
<fact14>Mean corpuscular volume: 78.2 μm3</fact14>
<fact15>Platelet count: 190,000/mm3</fact15>
<fact16>Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: 56 mm/h</fact16>
What complications is this patient at risk for?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms and laboratory results, particularly the <fact3>fatigue and joint pain</fact3> for the past <fact4>4 months</fact4>, <fact5>low blood pressure</fact5>, <fact7>absent radial pulse on one side and weak on the other</fact7>, <fact8>low hemoglobin</fact8>, and <fact16>elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate</fact16>, it suggests a diagnosis of Takayasu arteritis. This condition is known for affecting the large arteries, including those supplying blood to the head and neck, which can lead to various complications. Among the options provided, the patient is at risk for complications such as Amaurosis fugax, which is a temporary loss of vision due to reduced blood flow to the retina, a known complication in patients with Takayasu arteritis due to the involvement of the arteries supplying the head and neck. The answer is {A}.

question:
A 61-year-old man with schizophrenia in a locked inpatient psychiatry unit was observed making an unusual smacking motion with his lips, pursing his mouth, and blinking excessively. These symptoms started slowly about 2 weeks ago and have become more pronounced, but they do not seem to bother the patient. He resides in an inpatient psychiatric facility where he has been successfully treated with haloperidol for the past several months. His physical exam and vitals are within normal limits. Which of the following accurately describes his symptoms?
A) Akathisia
B) Tardive dyskinesia
C) Acute dystonia
D) Pseudoparkinsonism
E) Palsy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>61-year-old man with schizophrenia</fact1> in a locked inpatient psychiatry unit was observed making an <fact2>unusual smacking motion with his lips, pursing his mouth, and blinking excessively</fact2>. These <fact3>symptoms started slowly about 2 weeks ago</fact3> and have become more pronounced, but they do not seem to bother the <fact1>patient</fact1>. He resides in an inpatient psychiatric facility where he has been successfully treated with <fact4>haloperidol for the past several months</fact4>. His <fact5>physical exam and vitals are within normal limits</fact5>. Which of the following accurately describes his <fact2>symptoms</fact2>?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>61-year-old man with schizophrenia</fact1> has been treated with <fact4>haloperidol for the past several months</fact4> and has developed <fact2>symptoms of unusual smacking motion with his lips, pursing his mouth, and blinking excessively</fact2> that <fact3>started slowly about 2 weeks ago</fact3>, the most likely condition is tardive dyskinesia. Tardive dyskinesia is a side effect of long-term use of antipsychotic medications like haloperidol, characterized by repetitive, involuntary, purposeless movements. It often appears after months or years of treatment and can be irreversible. Given the <fact5>normal physical exam and vitals</fact5> and the specific nature of the <fact2>symptoms</fact2>, the correct answer is {B}.

question:
A 62-year-old man presents to the physician because of incomplete healing of a chest wound. He recently had a triple coronary artery bypass graft 3 weeks ago. His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension for the past 25 years. Clinical examination shows the presence of wound dehiscence in the lower 3rd of the sternal region. The wound surface shows the presence of dead necrotic tissue with pus. Computed tomography (CT) of the thorax shows a small fluid collection with fat stranding in the perisurgical soft tissues. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of the patient?
A) Surgical debridement
B) Negative pressure wound management
C) Sternal dressings
D) Sternal wiring
E) Sternal fixation
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>62-year-old man</fact1> presents to the physician because of <fact2>incomplete healing of a chest wound</fact2>. He recently had a <fact3>triple coronary artery bypass graft 3 weeks ago</fact3>. His past medical history is significant for <fact4>type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension for the past 25 years</fact4>. Clinical examination shows the presence of <fact5>wound dehiscence in the lower 3rd of the sternal region</fact5>. The wound surface shows the presence of <fact6>dead necrotic tissue with pus</fact6>. Computed tomography (CT) of the thorax shows a <fact7>small fluid collection with fat stranding in the perisurgical soft tissues</fact7>. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of the patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation with <fact2>incomplete healing of a chest wound</fact2> and <fact5>wound dehiscence in the lower 3rd of the sternal region</fact5>, along with the presence of <fact6>dead necrotic tissue with pus</fact6> and a <fact7>small fluid collection with fat stranding in the perisurgical soft tissues</fact7> on CT, the most appropriate next step is to remove the necrotic tissue and manage the infection. Given the patient's history of <fact3>recent coronary artery bypass graft</fact3> and <fact4>type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension</fact4>, which may impair healing, the best option is surgical debridement to promote wound healing and prevent further complications. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 28-year-old woman with no significant past medical history presents to her primary care physician with increased menstrual bleeding over the past three months. She also notes easy bruising and bleeding from her gums when brushing her teeth. She is sexually active with multiple partners and has no history of intravenous drug use. Physical exam is remarkable for petechiae and scattered ecchymoses on the patient's bilateral upper and lower extremities. Urine beta-HCG is negative. Laboratory results are as follows: Hgb 13.0 g/dL, WBCs 6,000/mL, platelets 95,000/mL, PT 13.2s, aPTT 30s. Peripheral blood smear shows normocytic, normochromic red blood cells and few platelets with no morphologic abnormalities. Which diagnostic study should be performed next?
A) Serum factor VIII levels and von Willebrand factor activity
B) Vitamin B12 and folate levels
C) Measurement of ADAMTS13 activity
D) HIV and HCV testing
E) Bone marrow aspiration
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>28-year-old woman</fact1> with no significant past medical history presents to her primary care physician with <fact2>increased menstrual bleeding</fact2> over the past three months. She also notes <fact3>easy bruising</fact3> and <fact4>bleeding from her gums when brushing her teeth</fact4>. She is <fact5>sexually active with multiple partners</fact5> and has no history of intravenous drug use. Physical exam is remarkable for <fact6>petechiae and scattered ecchymoses</fact6> on the patient's bilateral upper and lower extremities. <fact7>Urine beta-HCG is negative</fact7>. Laboratory results are as follows: <fact8>Hgb 13.0 g/dL</fact8>, <fact9>WBCs 6,000/mL</fact9>, <fact10>platelets 95,000/mL</fact10>, <fact11>PT 13.2s</fact11>, <fact12>aPTT 30s</fact12>. <fact13>Peripheral blood smear shows normocytic, normochromic red blood cells and few platelets with no morphologic abnormalities</fact13>. Which diagnostic study should be performed next?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>increased menstrual bleeding</fact2>, <fact3>easy bruising</fact3>, and <fact4>bleeding from her gums when brushing her teeth</fact4>, along with the physical exam findings of <fact6>petechiae and scattered ecchymoses</fact6>, a bleeding disorder is likely. The laboratory results show a low <fact10>platelet count of 95,000/mL</fact10>, which could be indicative of thrombocytopenia. However, the <fact13>peripheral blood smear</fact13> does not show any platelet morphologic abnormalities, making it less likely that the thrombocytopenia is due to a production problem in the bone marrow. Given the patient's history of being <fact5>sexually active with multiple partners</fact5>, it is essential to consider the possibility of an infectious cause for her thrombocytopenia, such as HIV or HCV infection, which can cause immune-mediated platelet destruction. Therefore, the next diagnostic study should be <fact14>HIV and HCV testing</fact14>. The answer is {D}.

question:
An asymptomatic 65-year-old woman is found to have T-score of -2.6 SD on routine bone mineral density screening. She has a 10-year history of hypertension and an esophageal stricture due to severe gastroesophageal reflux disease. She was diagnosed with endometrial hyperplasia 20 years ago and treated with medroxyprogesterone. Menarche started at 11 years of age and her last menstrual period was 8 years ago. Her last mammography and PAP smear 6 months ago showed no abnormalities. Her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 45 years. The patient does not have any children. Current medications include lansoprazole and hydrochlorothiazide. Her blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Treatment is begun with a drug that prevents further bone resorption and reduces her risk of developing breast cancer. This drug puts her at an increased risk of which of the following adverse effects?
A) Mandibular osteonecrosis
B) Skin infections
C) Osteosarcoma
D) Hypercholesterolemia
E) Deep vein thrombosis
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
An asymptomatic <fact1>65-year-old woman</fact1> is found to have a <fact2>T-score of -2.6 SD</fact2> on routine bone mineral density screening. She has a <fact3>10-year history of hypertension</fact3> and an <fact4>esophageal stricture due to severe gastroesophageal reflux disease</fact4>. She was diagnosed with <fact5>endometrial hyperplasia 20 years ago</fact5> and treated with <fact6>medroxyprogesterone</fact6>. <fact7>Menarche started at 11 years of age</fact7> and her <fact8>last menstrual period was 8 years ago</fact8>. Her <fact9>last mammography and PAP smear 6 months ago showed no abnormalities</fact9>. Her <fact10>mother died of breast cancer at the age of 45 years</fact10>. The patient does not have any children. Current medications include <fact11>lansoprazole and hydrochlorothiazide</fact11>. Her <fact12>blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg</fact12>. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Treatment is begun with a drug that prevents further bone resorption and reduces her risk of developing <fact13>breast cancer</fact13>. This drug puts her at an increased risk of which of the following adverse effects?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's profile, particularly her <fact1>age of 65 years</fact1>, <fact2>low T-score indicating osteoporosis</fact2>, and <fact13>family history of breast cancer</fact13>, the treatment likely initiated is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) or an aromatase inhibitor, but given the context of preventing bone resorption and reducing breast cancer risk, the most likely option is a SERM or a drug like tamoxifen or raloxifene. However, these drugs are not primarily associated with preventing bone resorption; instead, drugs like bisphosphonates are. Bisphosphonates can cause gastrointestinal side effects but are more commonly associated with <fact4>esophageal issues</fact4>, which could be problematic given her <fact4>esophageal stricture</fact4>, but the most specific adverse effect listed that is associated with bisphosphonates is <fact14>not explicitly listed</fact14>. Nonetheless, among the provided options, bisphosphonates are known to increase the risk of <fact15>osteonecrosis of the jaw (ONJ)</fact15>, particularly in patients with certain risk factors such as those taking high doses of these medications, especially for cancer-related conditions. The correct answer is {A}.

question:
A 17-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. The patient was an unrestrained driver in a head-on collision. He has a past medical history of asthma, depression, and anxiety. He is not currently taking any medications. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, pulse is 115/min, respirations are 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient's cardiopulmonary exam is within normal limits. The patient is breathing on his own and has strong distal pulses. Ultimately, the patient is discharged with follow up instructions after no significant fractures or injuries are found. The patient then presents 4 months later to his primary doctor with weakness. The patient's strength in his upper extremities is 1/5. He has reduced sensation in his upper extremities as well. The patient's lower extremities reveal 5/5 strength with intact sensation. A chest radiograph and basic labs are ordered. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Cervical spine fracture
B) Intracranial hemorrhage
C) Syringomyelia
D) Brachial plexopathy
E) Conversion disorder
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>17-year-old male</fact1> presents to the emergency department after a <fact2>motor vehicle accident</fact2>. The patient was an unrestrained driver in a <fact3>head-on collision</fact3>. He has a past medical history of <fact4>asthma, depression, and anxiety</fact4>. He is not currently taking any medications. His <fact5>temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C)</fact5>, <fact6>blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg</fact6>, <fact7>pulse is 115/min</fact7>, <fact8>respirations are 22/min</fact8>, and <fact9>oxygen saturation is 99% on room air</fact9>. The patient's cardiopulmonary exam is within normal limits. The patient is breathing on his own and has strong distal pulses. Ultimately, the patient is discharged with follow up instructions after no significant <fact10>fractures or injuries</fact10> are found. The patient then presents 4 months later to his primary doctor with <fact11>weakness</fact11>. The patient's strength in his upper extremities is <fact12>1/5</fact12>. He has reduced sensation in his upper extremities as well. The patient's lower extremities reveal <fact13>5/5 strength with intact sensation</fact13>. A chest radiograph and basic labs are ordered. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's history of a <fact2>motor vehicle accident</fact2> involving a <fact3>head-on collision</fact3> and the delayed presentation of <fact11>weakness</fact11> with significant impairment in the upper extremities (<fact12>1/5 strength</fact12>) but not in the lower extremities (<fact13>5/5 strength with intact sensation</fact13>), the most plausible explanation is an injury affecting the nerves supplying the upper limbs. The absence of significant <fact10>fractures or injuries</fact10> at the time of the accident and the specific pattern of weakness point towards a diagnosis of brachial plexopathy, which involves damage to the nerves of the brachial plexus. This condition can result from trauma, such as that experienced in a <fact2>motor vehicle accident</fact2>, and may present with delayed symptoms. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 70-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for 1 day. Computed tomography shows a small bowel perforation. The patient is prepared for emergent exploratory laparotomy. She is sedated with midazolam, induced with propofol, intubated, and maintained on nitrous oxide and isoflurane for the duration of the surgery. A single perforation in the terminal ileum is diagnosed intraoperatively and successfully repaired. The patient is transferred to the intensive care unit. The ventilator is set at an FiO2 of 50%, tidal volume of 1000 mL, respiratory rate of 12/min, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 2.5 cm H2O. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 111/50 mm Hg. She is responsive to painful stimuli. Lung examination shows bilateral rales. Abdominal examination shows a distended abdomen and intact abdominal surgical incisions. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis shows:
pH 7.44
pO2 54 mm Hg
pCO2 31 mm Hg
HCO3- 22 mm Hg
Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?"
A) Increase the FiO2
B) Extubate
C) Increase the tidal volume
D) Increase PEEP
E) Increase the respiratory rate
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>70-year-old woman</fact1> is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of <fact2>abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting</fact2> for 1 day. Computed tomography shows a <fact3>small bowel perforation</fact3>. The patient is prepared for emergent exploratory laparotomy. She is sedated with midazolam, induced with propofol, intubated, and maintained on nitrous oxide and isoflurane for the duration of the surgery. A single <fact4>perforation in the terminal ileum</fact4> is diagnosed intraoperatively and successfully repaired. The patient is transferred to the intensive care unit. The ventilator is set at an <fact5>FiO2 of 50%</fact5>, <fact6>tidal volume of 1000 mL</fact6>, <fact7>respiratory rate of 12/min</fact7>, and <fact8>positive end-expiratory pressure of 2.5 cm H2O</fact8>. Her <fact9>temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F)</fact9>, <fact10>pulse is 76/min</fact10>, and <fact11>blood pressure is 111/50 mm Hg</fact11>. She is responsive to painful stimuli. Lung examination shows <fact12>bilateral rales</fact12>. Abdominal examination shows a <fact13>distended abdomen</fact13> and intact abdominal surgical incisions. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis shows:
<fact14>pH 7.44</fact14>
<fact15>pO2 54 mm Hg</fact15>
<fact16>pCO2 31 mm Hg</fact16>
<fact17>HCO3- 22 mm Hg</fact17>
Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact15>pO2 of 54 mm Hg</fact15> on an <fact5>FiO2 of 50%</fact5>, this indicates hypoxemia that requires adjustment of the ventilator settings. Additionally, the presence of <fact12>bilateral rales</fact12> on lung examination suggests that increasing the positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) could help in improving oxygenation by preventing alveolar collapse. Therefore, the best next step in the management of this patient is to increase the PEEP. The answer is {D}.

question:
A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a low-grade fever, worsening fatigue, and mild intermittent abdominal pain that is not affected by eating. He reports that over the last 6 months he slept a lot more than usual and lost 14.9 kg (33 lbs) without trying to lose weight. He also complains of chest pain and shortness of breath that is worse when he is working and in the yard. There is no significant family history. His long-standing male partner passed away 2 years ago in a fatal car accident. His blood pressure is 145/75 mm Hg, the pulse is 90/min, the respiratory rate is 23/min, and the temperature is 38°C (100.5°F). On physical examination, he has pale mucous membranes, conjunctival hemorrhages, and petechiae on his lower extremities. There is a new-onset high-pitched blowing diastolic murmur best heard over the right upper sternal border. His head bobs with each heartbeat. There are small, painless, red macules on both palms. His spleen is palpable 3 cm below the left costal margin. His laboratory results are shown below.
Hemoglobin 8.4 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 72 µm3
Platelet count 400,000/mm3
Leukocytes 6,000/mm3
Serum ferritin 8 ng/mL
Serum iron 27 µg/dL
Total iron-binding capacity 450 µg/dL
Colonoscopy with biopsy is later performed showing a neoplastic growth in the descending colon. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for his cardiac findings?
A) Viridans streptococci
B) Treponema pallidum
C) Malignant colonic neoplasm
D) Collagen vascular disease
E) Group D streptococci
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>62-year-old man</fact1> presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a <fact2>low-grade fever, worsening fatigue, and mild intermittent abdominal pain</fact2> that is not affected by eating. He reports that over the last <fact3>6 months</fact3> he slept a lot more than usual and lost <fact4>14.9 kg (33 lbs)</fact4> without trying to lose weight. He also complains of <fact5>chest pain and shortness of breath</fact5> that is worse when he is working and in the yard. There is no significant family history. His long-standing male partner passed away <fact6>2 years ago</fact6> in a fatal car accident. His <fact7>blood pressure is 145/75 mm Hg</fact7>, the <fact8>pulse is 90/min</fact8>, the <fact9>respiratory rate is 23/min</fact9>, and the <fact10>temperature is 38°C (100.5°F)</fact10>. On physical examination, he has <fact11>pale mucous membranes, conjunctival hemorrhages, and petechiae on his lower extremities</fact11>. There is a new-onset <fact12>high-pitched blowing diastolic murmur</fact12> best heard over the right upper sternal border. His head bobs with each heartbeat. There are small, painless, red macules on both palms. His <fact13>spleen is palpable 3 cm below the left costal margin</fact13>. His laboratory results are shown below.
<fact14>Hemoglobin 8.4 g/dL</fact14>
<fact15>Mean corpuscular volume 72 µm3</fact15>
<fact16>Platelet count 400,000/mm3</fact16>
<fact17>Leukocytes 6,000/mm3</fact17>
<fact18>Serum ferritin 8 ng/mL</fact18>
<fact19>Serum iron 27 µg/dL</fact19>
<fact20>Total iron-binding capacity 450 µg/dL</fact20>
<fact21>Colonoscopy with biopsy</fact21> is later performed showing a <fact22>neoplastic growth in the descending colon</fact22>. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for his cardiac findings?

Answer:
Considering the patient's presentation, the <fact1>62-year-old man</fact1> has symptoms of <fact2>low-grade fever, worsening fatigue, and mild intermittent abdominal pain</fact2> along with significant weight loss of <fact4>14.9 kg (33 lbs)</fact4> over <fact3>6 months</fact3>, suggesting a chronic illness. The presence of <fact5>chest pain and shortness of breath</fact5> indicates possible cardiac involvement. The physical examination findings of <fact11>pale mucous membranes, conjunctival hemorrhages, and petechiae on his lower extremities</fact11> suggest anemia, which is confirmed by the low <fact14>hemoglobin level of 8.4 g/dL</fact14>. The new-onset <fact12>high-pitched blowing diastolic murmur</fact12> is indicative of aortic regurgitation. Given the patient's age and the absence of a significant family history of cardiac disease, the most likely explanation for his cardiac findings is a condition that can cause aortic valve damage, such as endocarditis. Among the options provided, the most likely cause of endocarditis in this context, considering the patient's <fact22>neoplastic growth in the descending colon</fact22> found on <fact21>colonoscopy with biopsy</fact21>, is Streptococcus bovis (also known as Group D streptococci), which is associated with colorectal cancer. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 65-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a neck mass. He first noticed a firm mass on the anterior aspect of his neck approximately 4 months ago. The mass is painless and has not increased in size since then. He has also noticed occasional fatigue and has gained 10 pounds in the past 4 months despite no change in his diet or exercise frequency. His past medical history is notable for gout for which he takes allopurinol. He denies any prior thyroid disorder. He runs 4 times per week and eats a balanced diet of mostly fruits and vegetables. He does not smoke and drinks a glass of wine with dinner. His family history is notable for medullary thyroid cancer in his maternal uncle. His temperature is 97.8°F (36.6°C), blood pressure is 127/72 mmHg, pulse is 87/min, and respirations are 19/min. On exam, he has a firm, symmetric, and stone-firm thyroid. A biopsy of this patient's lesion would most likely demonstrate which of the following findings?
A) Diffuse infiltrate of lymphoid cells destroying thyroid follicles
B) Dense fibroinflammatory infiltrate
C) Papillary projections with dystrophically calcified regions
D) Pleomorphic undifferentiated infiltrative cells with necrosis
E) Stromal amyloid deposition
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>65-year-old man</fact1> presents to his primary care physician with a <fact2>neck mass</fact2>. He first noticed a firm mass on the <fact3>anterior aspect of his neck</fact3> approximately <fact4>4 months ago</fact4>. The mass is <fact5>painless</fact5> and has not increased in size since then. He has also noticed <fact6>occasional fatigue</fact6> and has gained <fact7>10 pounds in the past 4 months</fact7> despite no change in his diet or exercise frequency. His past medical history is notable for <fact8>gout</fact8> for which he takes <fact9>allopurinol</fact9>. He denies any prior <fact10>thyroid disorder</fact10>. He runs <fact11>4 times per week</fact11> and eats a balanced diet of mostly <fact12>fruits and vegetables</fact12>. He does not smoke and drinks a glass of wine with dinner. His family history is notable for <fact13>medullary thyroid cancer</fact13> in his maternal uncle. His <fact14>temperature is 97.8°F (36.6°C)</fact14>, <fact15>blood pressure is 127/72 mmHg</fact15>, <fact16>pulse is 87/min</fact16>, and <fact17>respirations are 19/min</fact17>. On exam, he has a <fact18>firm, symmetric, and stone-firm thyroid</fact18>. A biopsy of this patient's lesion would most likely demonstrate which of the following findings?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation, particularly the <fact2>neck mass</fact2> located on the <fact3>anterior aspect of his neck</fact3>, which is <fact5>painless</fact5> and has not changed in size, along with the <fact18>firm, symmetric, and stone-firm thyroid</fact18> found on examination, suggests a possible thyroid-related pathology. The family history of <fact13>medullary thyroid cancer</fact13> is a significant clue. Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is known to be associated with a genetic predisposition and can present as a firm thyroid mass. A characteristic histological feature of MTC is the presence of <fact19>stromal amyloid deposition</fact19>, which is not mentioned in the provided options but given the closest relation to the question we can infer option {E} is the correct answer.

question:
A 21-year-old man comes to the physician because of pruritus and a hypopigmented rash on his upper body for 5 days. He first noticed the symptoms after returning from a business trip last week in the Bahamas. While he was there, he visited a couple of beaches and went hiking with some coworkers. The rash initially started as a single lesion on his upper back but since then has extended to his shoulders. He has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus controlled with an insulin pump. He works as an office manager and has no known exposure to melanocytotoxic chemicals. He has been sexually active with three female partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. He is 183 cm (6 ft) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 23.9 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. A photograph of the rash is shown. One month ago, his hemoglobin A1C was 7.8%. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
A) Wood lamp examination
B) Skin culture
C) Potassium hydroxide preparation
D) Skin biopsy
E) Antinuclear antibody testing
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>21-year-old man</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>pruritus and a hypopigmented rash</fact2> on his upper body for <fact3>5 days</fact3>. He first noticed the symptoms after returning from a <fact4>business trip last week in the Bahamas</fact4>. While he was there, he visited a couple of <fact5>beaches</fact5> and went <fact6"hiking</fact6> with some coworkers. The rash initially started as a single lesion on his upper back but since then has extended to his shoulders. He has a history of <fact7>type 1 diabetes mellitus controlled with an insulin pump</fact7>. He works as an office manager and has no known exposure to <fact8>melanocytotoxic chemicals</fact8>. He has been sexually active with three female partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. He is <fact9>183 cm (6 ft) tall</fact9> and weighs <fact10>80 kg (176 lb)</fact10>; BMI is <fact11>23.9 kg/m2</fact11>. His <fact12>temperature is 37.2°C (99°F)</fact12>, <fact13>pulse is 78/min</fact13>, and <fact14>blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg</fact14>. A photograph of the rash is shown. One month ago, his <fact15>hemoglobin A1C was 7.8%</fact15>. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>pruritus and a hypopigmented rash</fact2> that started after visiting <fact5>beaches</fact5> and going <fact6"hiking</fact6> in the Bahamas, along with the absence of exposure to <fact8>melanocytotoxic chemicals</fact8>, a fungal infection is a likely cause. The fact that the rash is hypopigmented also points towards a fungal etiology, such as pityriasis versicolor. A <fact16>potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation</fact16> is commonly used to diagnose fungal infections by demonstrating the presence of fungal elements. Therefore, the most likely method to confirm the diagnosis is option {C}.

question:
A 3-year-old male was brought to the pediatrician with severe lip lacerations, with a portion of his tongue appearing to be bitten off, as well as missing portions of the fingers on his right hand. A family history is notable for two similar cases in male cousins on the mother's side. A urinalysis revealed a high level of uric acid. Which of the following is the mode of inheritance for this disorder?
A) X-linked recessive
B) X-linked dominant
C) Autosomal dominant
D) Autosomal recessvie
E) Maternally inherited mitochondrial defect
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>3-year-old male</fact1> was brought to the pediatrician with <fact2>severe lip lacerations, with a portion of his tongue appearing to be bitten off, as well as missing portions of the fingers on his right hand</fact2>. A <fact3>family history</fact3> is notable for <fact4>two similar cases in male cousins on the mother's side</fact4>. A <fact5>urinalysis revealed a high level of uric acid</fact5>. Which of the following is the mode of inheritance for this disorder?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>3-year-old male</fact1> patient and the <fact3>family history</fact3> of <fact4>two similar cases in male cousins on the mother's side</fact4>, it suggests that the disorder is linked to the X chromosome and primarily affects males. The symptoms described, including <fact2>severe lip lacerations and missing portions of the fingers</fact2>, along with the <fact5>high level of uric acid</fact5> in the urinalysis, are indicative of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, a condition known for its association with uric acid overproduction and severe physical and behavioral manifestations. Given that Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is caused by a mutation in the HPRT1 gene located on the X chromosome and predominantly affects males, the mode of inheritance is X-linked recessive. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 45-year-old G5P4105 presents to her gynecologist’s office with six months of increasingly heavy periods. She now soaks one super absorbent tampon every two hours for five days each cycle. Her cycles have also become irregular, with intermenstrual bleeding for the last two months. She now experiences significant dysmenorrhea, requiring 400 mg ibuprofen every four hours for the majority of each menses. In addition, she reports new onset mild dyspareunia with intercourse and a “heavy feeling” in her pelvis. She has also noticed increased urinary frequency but denies bowel changes. The patient has a past medical history of obesity and type II diabetes on metformin. Her last child was born four years ago, and she has had five spontaneous vaginal deliveries. At this office visit, temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 137/84 mmHg, pulse is 87/min, and respirations are 14/min. Which of the following physical exam findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
A) Rectouterine septum nodularity
B) Globular 10-week sized uterus
C) Adnexal mass
D) Irregular 14-week sized uterus
E) No remarkable physical exam finding
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>45-year-old G5P4105</fact1> presents to her gynecologist’s office with <fact2>six months of increasingly heavy periods</fact2>. She now soaks <fact3>one super absorbent tampon every two hours for five days each cycle</fact3>. Her cycles have also become <fact4>irregular, with intermenstrual bleeding for the last two months</fact4>. She now experiences <fact5>significant dysmenorrhea, requiring 400 mg ibuprofen every four hours for the majority of each menses</fact5>. In addition, she reports <fact6>new onset mild dyspareunia with intercourse</fact6> and a “<fact7>heavy feeling” in her pelvis</fact7>. She has also noticed <fact8>increased urinary frequency</fact8> but denies bowel changes. The patient has a past medical history of <fact9>obesity</fact9> and <fact10>type II diabetes on metformin</fact10>. Her last child was born <fact11>four years ago</fact11>, and she has had <fact12>five spontaneous vaginal deliveries</fact12>. At this office visit, <fact13>temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C)</fact13>, <fact14>blood pressure is 137/84 mmHg</fact14>, <fact15>pulse is 87/min</fact15>, and <fact16>respirations are 14/min</fact16>. Which of the following physical exam findings is most likely to be present in this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms, including <fact2>six months of increasingly heavy periods</fact2>, <fact3>one super absorbent tampon every two hours for five days each cycle</fact3>, <fact4>irregular cycles with intermenstrual bleeding</fact4>, <fact5>significant dysmenorrhea</fact5>, <fact6>mild dyspareunia</fact6>, and a “<fact7>heavy feeling” in her pelvis</fact7>, along with <fact8>increased urinary frequency</fact8>, the most likely diagnosis is uterine fibroids. Uterine fibroids can cause heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic pressure or pain, and increased urinary frequency due to the size of the fibroids pressing on the bladder. Given the symptoms, the physical exam finding most likely to be present is a <fact18>globular 10-week sized uterus</fact18>, which is characteristic of uterine fibroids. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department from his home complaining of dyspnea. He is alert and oriented. The following arterial blood gas readings are drawn: pH: 7.33 (Normal: 7.35-7.45), pCO2: 70 mmHg (Normal: 35-45 mmHg), HCO3 33 (Normal: 21-26 mEq/L) Which of the following is most likely to have produced this patient’s condition?
A) Panic attack
B) Mechanical ventilation
C) Diabetic ketoacidosis
D) Pulmonary embolus
E) Chronic obstructive bronchitis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>65-year-old male</fact1> presents to the emergency department from his home complaining of <fact2>dyspnea</fact2>. He is <fact3>alert and oriented</fact3>. The following arterial blood gas readings are drawn: <fact4>pH: 7.33</fact4> (Normal: 7.35-7.45), <fact5>pCO2: 70 mmHg</fact5> (Normal: 35-45 mmHg), <fact6>HCO3 33</fact6> (Normal: 21-26 mEq/L) Which of the following is most likely to have produced this patient’s condition?

Answer: 
Analyzing the situation, the <fact1>65-year-old male</fact1> presents with <fact2>dyspnea</fact2> and is <fact3>alert and oriented</fact3>, indicating that he is experiencing respiratory distress but is still conscious and able to communicate. The arterial blood gas readings reveal a <fact4>pH of 7.33</fact4>, which is slightly acidic, a significantly elevated <fact5>pCO2 of 70 mmHg</fact5>, and an increased <fact6>HCO3 of 33</fact6>. These values suggest a state of respiratory acidosis with some degree of metabolic compensation. Among the options provided, the condition that is most likely to have produced this patient’s condition is one that would lead to hypoventilation and retention of CO2. Given the elevated <fact5>pCO2</fact5> and the patient's symptoms of <fact2>dyspnea</fact2>, the most likely cause is chronic obstructive bronchitis, which would impair the patient's ability to ventilate adequately. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of multiple episodes of nonbilious emesis for 3 days. The vomitus consists of undigested food and he has also had dark brown emesis twice today. He has been having early satiety during this period. He has had progressive severe episodic epigastric pain and dyspepsia for the past week. The pain is partially relieved with food or over-the-counter antacids, but worsens at night and several hours after eating. He has also had a weight gain of 2 kg (4.4 lbs) during this period. His father underwent surgery for colon cancer 3 years ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 15 years. He drinks two to three beers daily. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 106/min and blood pressure is 108/68 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. The abdomen is mildly tender to palpation in the left upper quadrant; there is a tympanitic mass in the epigastrium. A succussion splash is heard with a stethoscope when the patient is rocked back and forth at the hips. Bowel sounds are reduced. Rectal examination is unremarkable. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:
Na+ 135 mEq/L
K+ 3.3 mEq/L
Cl- 97 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 46 mg/dL
Glucose 77 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.4 mg/dL
Which of the following is the underlying cause of this patient's vomiting?"
A) Inflammation and edema
B) Abnormal gastric rotation
C) Neoplastic growth
D) Scarring and fibrosis
E) Walled-off pancreatic fluid collection
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>36-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department because of <fact2>multiple episodes of nonbilious emesis for 3 days</fact2>. The vomitus consists of undigested food and he has also had <fact3>dark brown emesis twice today</fact3>. He has been having <fact4>early satiety during this period</fact4>. He has had <fact5>progressive severe episodic epigastric pain and dyspepsia for the past week</fact5>. The pain is partially relieved with food or over-the-counter antacids, but worsens at night and several hours after eating. He has also had a <fact6>weight gain of 2 kg (4.4 lbs) during this period</fact6>. His father underwent surgery for colon cancer 3 years ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 15 years. He drinks two to three beers daily. His <fact7>temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F)</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 106/min</fact8> and <fact9>blood pressure is 108/68 mm Hg</fact9>. Examination shows <fact10>dry mucous membranes</fact10>. The abdomen is mildly tender to palpation in the left upper quadrant; there is a <fact11>tympanitic mass in the epigastrium</fact11>. A <fact12>succussion splash is heard with a stethoscope when the patient is rocked back and forth at the hips</fact12>. <fact13>Bowel sounds are reduced</fact13>. Rectal examination is unremarkable. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:
<fact14>Na+ 135 mEq/L</fact14>
<fact15>K+ 3.3 mEq/L</fact15>
<fact16>Cl- 97 mEq/L</fact16>
<fact17>Urea nitrogen 46 mg/dL</fact17>
<fact18>Glucose 77 mg/dL</fact18>
<fact19>Creatinine 1.4 mg/dL</fact19>
Which of the following is the underlying cause of this patient's vomiting?

Answer: 
Analyzing the situation, the <fact1>36-year-old man</fact1> is experiencing <fact2>multiple episodes of nonbilious emesis for 3 days</fact2> along with <fact3>dark brown emesis twice today</fact3> and <fact4>early satiety during this period</fact4>. These symptoms, combined with the presence of a <fact11>tympanitic mass in the epigastrium</fact11> and a <fact12>succussion splash heard with a stethoscope when the patient is rocked back and forth at the hips</fact12>, are highly suggestive of gastric outlet obstruction. The <fact5>progressive severe episodic epigastric pain and dyspepsia for the past week</fact5> that worsens at night and several hours after eating can be indicative of a peptic ulcer disease, but the weight gain and the specific findings on examination point more towards a mechanical obstruction. Among the options provided, the one that best explains the underlying cause of this patient's vomiting is a neoplastic growth causing obstruction, given the patient's family history of cancer and the presence of a mass. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 40-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of a painless right-sided scrotal swelling. The patient reports that he first noticed the swelling several weeks ago, but it is not always present. He has hypertension treated with enalapril. His father was diagnosed with a seminoma at the age of 25 years. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a 10-cm, soft, cystic, nontender right scrotal mass that transilluminates. The mass does not increase in size on coughing and it is possible to palpate normal tissue above the mass. There are no bowel sounds in the mass, and it does not reduce when the patient is in a supine position. Examination of the testis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the mass?
A) Patent processus vaginalis
B) Dilation of the pampiniform plexus
C) Twisting of the spermatic cord
D) Imbalance of fluid secretion and resorption by the tunica vaginalis
E) Impaired lymphatic drainage
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>40-year-old man</fact1> comes to the physician for the evaluation of a <fact2>painless right-sided scrotal swelling</fact2>. The patient reports that he first noticed the swelling several weeks ago, but it is not always present. He has <fact3>hypertension treated with enalapril</fact3>. His <fact4>father was diagnosed with a seminoma at the age of 25 years</fact4>. The patient has <fact5>smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years</fact5>. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a <fact6>10-cm, soft, cystic, nontender right scrotal mass that transilluminates</fact6>. The mass does not increase in size on coughing and it is possible to palpate normal tissue above the mass. There are no bowel sounds in the mass, and it does not reduce when the patient is in a supine position. Examination of the <fact7>testis shows no abnormalities</fact7>. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the mass?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation of a <fact2>painless right-sided scrotal swelling</fact2> and the physical examination findings of a <fact6>10-cm, soft, cystic, nontender right scrotal mass that transilluminates</fact6>, the most likely cause of the mass is an imbalance of fluid secretion and resorption by the tunica vaginalis, which is characteristic of a hydrocele. The fact that the mass does not increase in size on coughing, does not reduce when the patient is in a supine position, and the absence of bowel sounds in the mass help rule out other conditions such as hernias. Additionally, the normal examination of the <fact7>testis</fact7> suggests that the issue is not related to the testis itself. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 22-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician in April for seasonal allergies. She has suffered from seasonal allergies for the past 2 years and takes diphenhydramine as needed when her symptoms worsen. She has not yet seen a physician for her allergies. She reports that diphenhydramine has been helpful in controlling her symptoms, but she does not like feeling drowsy from the medication. Her past medical history is also notable for well-controlled asthma. She uses an albuterol inhaler on an as-needed basis. She smokes marijuana daily. Her temperature is 99.2°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg, pulse is 76/min, and respirations are 16/min. She has a prominent nasal crease. Her nasal turbinates are boggy and bluish-gray. She has copious thin and watery nasal mucus. The physician suggests replacing diphenhydramine with fexofenadine to improve her drowsiness. What characteristic of fexodenadine allows it to be less sedating than diphenhydramine?
A) Alpha-adrenergic antagonism
B) Beta-adrenergic antagonism
C) Muscarinic antagonism
D) Relative lipophobicity
E) Serotonergic antagonism
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>22-year-old woman</fact1> presents to her primary care physician in April for <fact2>seasonal allergies</fact2>. She has suffered from <fact2>seasonal allergies</fact2> for the past 2 years and takes <fact3>diphenhydramine</fact3> as needed when her symptoms worsen. She has not yet seen a physician for her <fact2>allergies</fact2>. She reports that <fact3>diphenhydramine</fact3> has been helpful in controlling her symptoms, but she does not like feeling <fact4>drowsy from the medication</fact4>. Her past medical history is also notable for <fact5>well-controlled asthma</fact5>. She uses an <fact6>albuterol inhaler</fact6> on an as-needed basis. She <fact7>smokes marijuana daily</fact7>. Her <fact8>temperature is 99.2°F (37.3°C)</fact8>, <fact9>blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg</fact9>, <fact10>pulse is 76/min</fact10>, and <fact11>respirations are 16/min</fact11>. She has a <fact12>prominent nasal crease</fact12>. Her <fact13>nasal turbinates are boggy and bluish-gray</fact13>. She has <fact14>copious thin and watery nasal mucus</fact14>. The physician suggests replacing <fact3>diphenhydramine</fact3> with <fact15>fexofenadine</fact15> to improve her <fact4>drowsiness</fact4>. What characteristic of <fact15>fexofenadine</fact15> allows it to be less sedating than <fact3>diphenhydramine</fact3>?

Answer: 
The key to answering this question lies in understanding the properties of <fact15>fexofenadine</fact15> that distinguish it from <fact3>diphenhydramine</fact3>, particularly in terms of sedation. <fact3>Diphenhydramine</fact3> is known to cause <fact4>drowsiness</fact4> due to its ability to cross the blood-brain barrier, a characteristic often associated with lipophilicity. Therefore, the characteristic of <fact15>fexofenadine</fact15> that allows it to be less sedating than <fact3>diphenhydramine</fact3> is its relative lipophobicity, which reduces its ability to cross the blood-brain barrier and cause sedation. The answer is {D}.

question:
A 24-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of an inability to urinate. She states that this has been one of many symptoms she has experienced lately. At times she has had trouble speaking and has noticed changes in her vision however these episodes occurred over a month ago and have resolved since then. Two days ago she experienced extreme pain in her face that was exacerbated with brushing her teeth and plucking out facial hairs. The patient has no relevant past medical history, however, the patient admits to being sexually abused by her boyfriend for the past year. Her current medications include ibuprofen for menstrual cramps. On physical exam it is noted that leftward gaze results in only the ipsilateral eye gazing leftward. The patient's initial workup is started in the emergency department. Her vital signs are within normal limits and you note a pale and frightened young lady awaiting further care. Which of the following is the best initial test for this patient's chief complaint?
A) Head CT
B) Head MRI
C) Lumbar puncture
D) Post void residual volumes
E) Domestic abuse screening and exploring patient's life stressors
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>24-year-old female</fact1> presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of an <fact2>inability to urinate</fact2>. She states that this has been one of many symptoms she has experienced lately. At times she has had trouble <fact3>speaking and has noticed changes in her vision</fact3> however these episodes occurred over a month ago and have resolved since then. Two days ago she experienced <fact4>extreme pain in her face</fact4> that was exacerbated with <fact5>brushing her teeth and plucking out facial hairs</fact5>. The patient has no relevant past medical history, however, the patient admits to being <fact6>sexually abused by her boyfriend for the past year</fact6>. Her current medications include ibuprofen for menstrual cramps. On physical exam it is noted that <fact7>leftward gaze results in only the ipsilateral eye gazing leftward</fact7>. The patient's initial workup is started in the emergency department. Her vital signs are within normal limits and you note a pale and frightened young lady awaiting further care. Which of the following is the best initial test for this patient's chief complaint?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's chief complaint of an <fact2>inability to urinate</fact2> along with other neurological symptoms such as <fact3>trouble speaking and changes in vision</fact3>, and the physical exam finding of <fact7>leftward gaze resulting in only the ipsilateral eye gazing leftward</fact7>, it is crucial to evaluate for potential neurological causes. Given the complexity of the patient's symptoms, including <fact4>extreme pain in her face</fact4> exacerbated by <fact5>brushing her teeth and plucking out facial hairs</fact5>, a comprehensive imaging study is necessary. Among the options provided, a Head MRI is the most appropriate initial test as it can provide detailed images of the brain and spinal cord, helping to identify any underlying neurological conditions that may be causing the patient's symptoms. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 33-year-old nurse is referred to an infectious disease specialist after she exhibited a PPD skin test with 17 mm of induration. She denies any cough, shortness of breath, hemoptysis, weight loss, fatigue, fevers, or night sweats over the last several months. Her temperature is 97.0°F (36.1°C), blood pressure is 120/81 mmHg, pulse is 82/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. An initial chest radiograph is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?
A) Isoniazid
B) No management indicated
C) Quantiferon gold
D) Repeat PPD in 1 week
E) Rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>33-year-old nurse</fact1> is referred to an infectious disease specialist after she exhibited a <fact2>PPD skin test with 17 mm of induration</fact2>. She denies any <fact3>cough, shortness of breath, hemoptysis, weight loss, fatigue, fevers, or night sweats</fact3> over the last several months. Her <fact4>temperature is 97.0°F (36.1°C)</fact4>, <fact5>blood pressure is 120/81 mmHg</fact5>, <fact6>pulse is 82/min</fact6>, <fact7>respirations are 15/min</fact7>, and <fact8>oxygen saturation is 98% on room air</fact8>. An initial <fact9>chest radiograph is unremarkable</fact9>. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?

Answer: 
Given the <fact1>33-year-old nurse's</fact1> <fact2>PPD skin test with 17 mm of induration</fact2> and the absence of any symptoms such as <fact3>cough, shortness of breath, hemoptysis, weight loss, fatigue, fevers, or night sweats</fact3>, it indicates latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI) rather than active tuberculosis disease. Her normal vital signs, including <fact4>temperature</fact4>, <fact5>blood pressure</fact5>, <fact6>pulse</fact6>, <fact7>respirations</fact7>, and <fact8>oxygen saturation</fact8>, along with an <fact9>unremarkable chest radiograph</fact9>, further support this diagnosis. The most appropriate management for LTBI is monotherapy with Isoniazid to prevent the progression to active tuberculosis disease. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A medical research study is evaluating an investigational novel drug (medication 1) compared with standard therapy (medication 2) in patients presenting to the emergency department with myocardial infarction (MI). The study enrolled a total of 3,000 subjects, 1,500 in each study arm. Follow-up was conducted at 45 days post-MI. The following are the results of the trial:
Endpoints Medication 1 Medication 2 P-Value
Primary: death from cardiac causes 134 210 0.03
Secondary: hyperkalemia 57 70 0.4
What is the number needed to treat (NNT) for the primary endpoint of death from cardiac causes? (Round to the nearest whole number.)
A) 5
B) 16
C) 20
D) 30
E) 50
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A medical research study is evaluating an <fact1>investigational novel drug (medication 1)</fact1> compared with <fact2>standard therapy (medication 2)</fact2> in patients presenting to the emergency department with <fact3>myocardial infarction (MI)</fact3>. The study enrolled a total of <fact4>3,000 subjects</fact4>, <fact5>1,500 in each study arm</fact5>. Follow-up was conducted at <fact6>45 days post-MI</fact6>. The following are the results of the trial:
Endpoints <fact7>Medication 1</fact7> <fact8>Medication 2</fact8> <fact9>P-Value</fact9>
Primary: <fact10>death from cardiac causes</fact10> <fact11>134</fact11> <fact12>210</fact12> <fact13>0.03</fact13>
Secondary: <fact14>hyperkalemia</fact14> <fact15>57</fact15> <fact16>70</fact16> <fact17>0.4</fact17>
